Ryanair ( RYAAY ) Getting Neutral News Coverage, Study Finds
Ryanair (RYAAY) Getting Neutral News Coverage, Study Finds
American Banking and Market News
November 16, 2018 Friday
Copyright 2018 American Banking and Market News All Rights Reserved
Length: 556 words
Body
Ryanair logo Press coverage about Ryanair (NASDAQ:RYAAY) has trended neutral on Friday, according to InfoTrie 
Sentiment Analysis. The research firm scores the sentiment of news coverage by reviewing more than 6,000 blog 
and news sources in real-time. The firm ranks coverage of publicly-traded companies on a scale of negative five to 
positive five, with scores closest to five being the most favorable. Ryanair earned a media sentiment score of 0.25 
on their scale. InfoTrie also gave media stories about the transportation company an news buzz score of 10 out of 
10, indicating that recent news coverage is extremely likely to have an effect on the stock's share price in the near 
term.  
Here are some of the news headlines that may have effected Ryanair's ranking: 
•
SHAREHOLDER ALERT: Pomerantz Law Firm Investigates Claims On Behalf of Investors of Ryanair 
Holdings plc â€“ RYAAY  (feeds.benzinga.com)
•
INVESTOR ACTION ALERT: The Schall Law Firm Announces the Filing of a Class Action Lawsuit Against 
Ryanair Holdings plc and Encourages Investors with Losses in Excess of $100,000 to Contact the Firm  
(finance.yahoo.com)
•
Glancy Prongay & Murray LLP Announces Investigation on Behalf of Ryanair Holdings plc Investors 
(RYAAY)  (finance.yahoo.com)
•
CLASS ACTION UPDATE for SFIX, CWH, OZK and RYAAY: Levi & Korsinsky, LLP Reminds Investors of 
Class Actions on Behalf of Shareholders  (finance.yahoo.com)
•
Struggling British airline Flybe exploring sale  (nasdaq.com)
NASDAQ:RYAAY  traded down $0.11 on Friday, hitting $79.99. 381,300 shares of the stock were exchanged, 
compared to its average volume of 407,504. The firm has a market capitalization of $19.95 billion, a PE ratio of 
11.35 and a beta of 0.74. The company has a debt-to-equity ratio of 0.62, a current ratio of 1.25 and a quick ratio of 
1.25. Ryanair has a fifty-two week low of $77.96 and a fifty-two week high of $127.61.  
Several equities analysts recently commented on the company. ValuEngine  upgraded Ryanair from a "sell" rating 
to a "hold" rating in a research note on Monday, September 17th. UBS Group  reiterated a "buy" rating on shares of 
Ryanair in a research note on Wednesday, August 15th. BidaskClub lowered Ryanair from a "hold" rating to a "sell" 
rating in a research note on Tuesday, August 7th. Royal Bank of Canada  reiterated a "buy" rating on shares of 
Ryanair in a research note on Thursday, August 16th. Finally, Raymond James lowered Ryanair from an 
"outperform" rating to a "market perform" rating in a research note on Thursday, August 9th. Two equities research 
Ryanair ( RYAAY ) Getting Neutral News Coverage, Study Finds
analysts have rated the stock with a sell rating, seven have given a hold rating and three have given a buy rating to 
the company. The company currently has an average rating of "Hold" and an average target price of $138.00.  
About Ryanair
Ryanair Holdings plc, together with its subsidiaries, provides scheduled-passenger airline services in Ireland, the 
United Kingdom, and Other European countries. The company is also involved in the provision of various ancillary 
services, such as non-flight scheduled services and Internet-related services; in-flight sale of beverages, food, and 
merchandise; and marketing accommodation services, holidays, car hire, and travel insurance through its Website.

Lafayette Investments Inc. Boosts Position in Ryanair Holdings plc ( RYAAY )
Lafayette Investments Inc. Boosts Position in Ryanair Holdings plc (RYAAY)
American Banking and Market News
November 16, 2018 Friday
Copyright 2018 American Banking and Market News All Rights Reserved
Length: 686 words
Body
Ryanair logo Lafayette Investments Inc. increased its stake in shares of  Ryanair Holdings plc (NASDAQ:RYAAY) 
by 11.7% in the 3rd quarter, according to the company in its most recent Form 13F filing with the SEC. The firm 
owned 60,255 shares of the transportation company's stock after purchasing an additional 6,310 shares during the 
quarter. Ryanair makes up  approximately  2.0% of Lafayette Investments Inc.'s portfolio, making the stock its 21st 
largest position. Lafayette Investments Inc.'s holdings in Ryanair were worth $5,787,000 as of its most recent SEC 
filing.  
Several other hedge funds also recently bought and sold shares of the stock. WCM Investment Management CA 
boosted its holdings in shares of  Ryanair by 7.6% during the third quarter. WCM Investment Management CA now 
owns 4,161,465 shares of the transportation company's stock worth $399,666,000 after purchasing an additional 
295,462 shares during the period.  Massachusetts Financial Services Co. MA lifted its stake in  Ryanair by 6.8% in 
the third quarter. Massachusetts Financial Services Co. MA now owns 2,713,082 shares of the transportation 
company's stock valued at $260,564,000 after acquiring an additional 173,885 shares during the last quarter.  
JPMorgan Chase & Co. lifted its stake in  Ryanair by 17.3% in the third quarter. JPMorgan Chase & Co. now owns 
1,983,410 shares of the transportation company's stock valued at $190,487,000 after acquiring an additional 
293,233 shares during the last quarter.  Thornburg Investment Management Inc. lifted its stake in  Ryanair by 4.4% 
in the third quarter. Thornburg Investment Management Inc. now owns 1,889,740 shares of the transportation 
company's stock valued at $181,491,000 after acquiring an additional 79,755 shares during the last quarter.  
Finally, Bank of America Corp DE lifted its stake in  Ryanair by 2.7% in the second quarter. Bank of America Corp 
DE now owns 561,841 shares of the transportation company's stock valued at $64,178,000 after acquiring an 
additional 15,020 shares during the last quarter. Institutional investors and hedge funds own  43.90% of the 
company's stock.  
Shares of Ryanair stock  opened at $80.10 on Friday. The firm has a market capitalization of $19.95 billion, a price-
to-earnings ratio of 11.36 and a beta of 0.74. The company has a debt-to-equity ratio of 0.62, a quick ratio of 1.25 
and a current ratio of 1.25. Ryanair Holdings plc has a 52-week low of $77.96 and a 52-week high of $127.61.  
RYAAY has been the topic of a number of recent analyst reports. ValuEngine  raised shares of Ryanair from a "sell" 
rating to a "hold" rating in a research report on Monday, September 17th. UBS Group  reissued a "buy" rating on 
shares of Ryanair in a report on Wednesday, August 15th. BidaskClub lowered shares of Ryanair from a "hold" 
rating to a "sell" rating in a report on Tuesday, August 7th. Royal Bank of Canada  reissued a "buy" rating on shares 
of Ryanair in a report on Thursday, August 16th. Finally, Raymond James lowered shares of Ryanair from an 
"outperform" rating to a "market perform" rating in a report on Thursday, August 9th. Two equities research analysts 
Lafayette Investments Inc. Boosts Position in Ryanair Holdings plc ( RYAAY )
have rated the stock with a sell rating, seven have issued  a hold rating and three have issued  a buy rating to the 
company. Ryanair presently has a consensus rating of "Hold" and an average price target of $138.00.  
Ryanair Profile
Ryanair Holdings plc, together with its subsidiaries, provides scheduled-passenger airline services in Ireland, the 
United Kingdom, and Other European countries. The company is also involved in the provision of various ancillary 
services, such as non-flight scheduled services and Internet-related services; in-flight sale of beverages, food, and 
merchandise; and marketing accommodation services, holidays, car hire, and travel insurance through its Website.

Body

(NASDAQ:RYAAY) by 7.5% in the 3rd quarter, according to its most recent 13F filing with the Securities and 
Exchange Commission (SEC). The firm owned 445,293 shares of the transportation company's stock after selling 
36,032 shares during the quarter. Thompson Siegel & Walmsley LLC owned 0.19% of Ryanair worth $42,766,000 
at the end of the most recent reporting period.

the period. Institutional investors and hedge funds own  43.90% of the company's stock.

UK-exposed stocks slide as Brexit fears intensify on government resignations Equities
UK-exposed stocks slide as Brexit fears intensify on government 
resignations; Equities
Financial Times (London, England)
November 16, 2018 Friday
Edition 1, Asian Edition
Copyright 2018 The Financial Times Limited All Rights Reserved
Section: COMPANIES AND MARKETS;BUSINESS; Pg. 21
Length: 436 words
Byline: BRYCE ELDER
Body
Stocks exposed to the UK economy tumbled yesterday as parliamentary resignations over Prime Minister Theresa 
May's draft EU withdrawal agreement threw the Brexit process into chaos.
Royal Bank of Scotland was hit by its biggest fall in more than two years, losing nearly 10 per cent on fears of 
slower economic growth, rising defaults, business disruption and the tail risk of a break-up under a Labour 
government.
A plunge for the pound helped support the multinational-heavy FTSE 100 index but sectors reliant on domestic 
earnings and those exposed to political risks were hit hard.
Indices tracking UK electricity companies, transport operators and retailers all fell more than 4 per cent while those 
tracking banking, telecoms and life insurance slipped about 3 per cent.
"UK earnings recovery is in full swing for UK plc," said Citigroup analyst Jonathan Stubbs. "This likely continues 
barring a hard landing in the UK or the end of the global cycle. Brexit-related risks could end this earnings 
recovery."
The FTSE 100, which takes an estimated three-quarters of revenue from outside the UK, ended the day little 
changed as investors switched into dollar and euro earners such as Unilever, Randgold Resources and Smirnoff 
owner Diageo. When priced in dollars, the UK blue-chip benchmark was down 1.4 per cent.
UK-exposed stocks slide as Brexit fears intensify on government resignations Equities
But fears about UK consumer sentiment hit housebuilders and leisure stocks, sending the mid-cap FTSE 250 lower 
as much as 2 per cent. Countryside Properties, buy-to-let lender One-Savings Bank and travel agent Thomas Cook 
were all under pressure. Bovis Homes fell even after the housebuilder said it had met sales targets for 2018 and 
would match full-year profit expectations. Bovis was down 7.2 per cent, Countryside and OneSavings dropped more 
than 9 per cent and Thomas Cook was 4.3 per cent lower.
EasyJet and Ryanair weakened about 7 per cent on concern that flights might be grounded by a no-deal split from 
the EU. Domestic airline Flybe, which earlier this week put itself up for sale, dropped 16 per cent.
"The risks of a disorderly outcome are significantly underpriced by the market," said Deutsche Bank strategist Oliver 
Harvey. Financial stocks including Lloyds priced in the likelihood of a more gradual path for interest rate rises 
eroding their net interest margins.
Speculation of a snap general election also weighed on regulated utilities and government outsourcers such as 
Capita, which dropped nearly 15 per cent.
Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn has pledged to take privatised companies back into public ownership and has 
threatened to cancel state contracts awarded to "rogue suppliers". See Lex
Graphic
 
Investors punished RBS with its biggest share price fall in two years
Load-Date: November 15, 2018
End of Document

Tourism revenues in Jordan reach $4.5 billion in 10 months Low cost flights to improve performance in coming 
months
Tourism revenues in Jordan reach $4.5 billion in 10 months; Low cost flights 
to improve performance in coming months
ANSA English Corporate Service
November 14, 2018 Wednesday 3:49 PM CET
©Copyright 2018 ANSA All Rights Reserved
Length: 291 words
Dateline: AMMAN 
Body
(ANSA) - NOVEMBER 14 -  Recovery of tourism sector in Jordan  appears well on track after revenues jumped to 
$4.5 billion, or 12.6 percent growth, during the first 10 months of 2018, central bank figures showed today. The 
numbers represent a leap in the volume of tourism performance in a country that has seen its economy heavily hit 
as a result of uncertainty in the region, according to officials.  Officials from tourism authorities told ANSA that the 
rock engraved city of Petra is seeing the highest number of visitors in years, as hotels run in full capacity while 
cruise ships docking in the port city of Aqaba are lining up with thousands of visitors on weekly basis. 
The government and tourism operators expect yet another increase in number of tourists during the coming period 
after the start of low cost flights to the kingdom from Europe such as Easy jet and Ryanair.  Officials from Jordan 
Tourism Board (JTB) said an aggressive promotion campaign, locally and internationally, played a significant role in 
attracting tourists to the kingdom. According to JTB,  the government has also supported plans to stimulate the 
charter and low-cost flights, allowing for the number of tourists to rise compared to the previous years. Tourism 
sector is considered the second main sources of foreign currency in a country that has no natural resources as its 
economy relies on services, remittances from expatriates in the gulf as well as foreign aid. The Arab spring dealt a 
heavy blow to tourism sector, forcing many companies and operators to shut down or scale down their operation, 
but officials from JTB hope the worst is gone after Syria war has eased up during the past months, coupled with 
reconciliation efforts in the war torn country.
Load-Date: November 14, 2018
End of Document
Investors put pressure on airlines as Brexit deadline looms Travel & leisure. Sector threat ; IAG, Ryanair and 
easyJet face demand for fuller explanation on con....
Investors put pressure on airlines as Brexit deadline looms; Travel & leisure. 
Sector threat ; IAG, Ryanair and easyJet face demand for fuller explanation 
on contingency planning
Financial Times (London, England)
November 14, 2018 Wednesday
Edition 1, USA Edition
Copyright 2018 The Financial Times Limited All Rights Reserved
Section: COMPANIES AND MARKETS;NEWS; Pg. 16
Length: 817 words
Byline: JOSH SPERO ; ATTRACTA MOONEY
Body
Investors are stepping up pressure on IAG, Ryanair and easyJet to explain how the airlines are preparing their 
businesses for a no-deal Brexit as fears rise that their aircraft will be grounded.
Shareholders have asked for meetings with airline bosses and board members as the Brexit deadline looms.
There are also growing concerns that UK-based investors might be forced to dump shares in the event of a no-deal 
Brexit or lose voting rights.
One big UK-based investor said: "We are due to see easyJet shortly, and will be pressing for more detail. It affects 
them as much as everyone else.
"They [the airlines] are putting contingency plans in place. It is going to be a major problem if they can't take off or 
land."
Another of the UK's biggest investors said portfolio managers at the asset manager had been pressing for more 
details on how the airlines would cope with a no-deal Brexit.
"It is not a simple question, and you can bet your bottom dollar the answer will be even more complex," he said.
Investors put pressure on airlines as Brexit deadline looms Travel & leisure. Sector threat ; IAG, Ryanair and 
easyJet face demand for fuller explanation on con....
"They are running the business, they are closer to the policymakers. If we got the answer that they weren't worried 
about it, it would raise a warning flag."
The European Commission is planning to give airlines no extra time to meet the EU's ownership requirements, 
according to Brussels' draft contingency plans. Under existing rules, airlines must prove they are 50 per cent EU 
owned and controlled to qualify for operating licences.
Ryanair and easyJet have tried to respond to the problem by preparing plans to take away voting rights of their non-
EU shareholders to ensure that they reach the 51 per cent threshold.
However, these moves would not go down well with shareholders as they would lose their say on issues from pay 
to the chairman's role.
Paul Lee, a corporate governance expert, said it would be a "terrible result" for UK-based investors if they were to 
lose their right to vote at airlines in the event of a no-deal Brexit.
"If you have shares that don't have voting rights, they are not shares. They are a warrant," he said.
With little time left ahead of Britain's scheduled March 29 exit, IAG remains the most reluctant to provide detailed 
assurances to investors about how it would address a no deal, declining to give guidance about whether, if forced, 
over the long term it would opt to be a British company or an EU one.
A report in Spanish newspaper El País over the weekend said that IAG had made it clear to authorities in Madrid 
that it would remain European.
Brexit throws up particular problems for IAG, as it owns British Airways but also EU-based airlines.
The problems have been compounded by the likelihood that a post-Brexit US-UK aviation agreement will be 
expected to require the Spanish-registered company to be majority-owned by UK parties.
"For traffic rights purposes, [IAG] needs to argue that BA is British to one side of the world, and to the other they 
need to argue that [IAG's other subsidiaries] Iberia, Vueling and Aer Lingus are solidly European," said Andrew 
Lobbenberg, analyst at HSBC.
He said supposing such an outcome could be sustainable after Brexit required "a suspension of disbelief".
To date, IAG has done little more than mention that it has "contingency plans" for Brexit; the response on the issue 
from Antonio Vázquez Romero, IAG chairman. Elsewhere, long-haul lowcost carrier Norwegian has a UK subsidiary 
in the same position as BA regarding the US, as does Virgin Atlantic. Sir Richard Branson owns 51 per cent of 
Virgin, making it majority-UKowned. But he is in the process of selling 31 per cent to Air France-KLM, which could 
complicate Virgin's access rights to the US. US airline Delta owns the remaining stake. In the event of a nodeal 
Brexit, Air France-KLM and Delta have agreed a deal to keep Virgin as the majority shareholder, protecting its US 
flight rights.
Norwegian said: "Structurally, Norwegian is well-positioned to protect our flying rights both in Europe and the UK, 
including in the unlikely event of a nodeal Brexit." Norwegian would use its main airline to keep flying around 
Europe and its UK one to fly to the US, if a UK-US agreement is reached.
In the case of IAG, if there is a no-deal Brexit, it would need to disfranchise non-EU shareholders, taking away 
voting rights, though this might leave BA in an awkward position on its profitable US flights. But even if everything 
went as smoothly as IAG is hoping for, there is no assurance it could maintain its corporate equilibrium indefinitely. 
HSBC's Mr Lobbenberg said: "The requirement that European airlines be controlled and owned by EU citizens is 
there in black and white." Additional reporting by Alex Barker in Brussels
'We will be pressing for more detail. It is going to be a major problem if they can't take off or land'
Investors put pressure on airlines as Brexit deadline looms Travel & leisure. Sector threat ; IAG, Ryanair and 
easyJet face demand for fuller explanation on con....

that they would lose voting rights Daniel Leal-Olivas/AFP/Getty Images

Holdings PLC 374.40 -10.60 544.00 338.20 5.53 249.60 865.2 Stagech 156.00 4.30 173.80 124.30 7.63 12.79 
678.7 ThomasCook 51.90 2.80 150.00 39.24 1.16 32.44 4577.6 TUI 1279 11.50 1816 1252.5 4.49 10.47 738.4 
Whitbrd?

Investors put pressure on airlines as Brexit deadline looms; Travel & leisure. 
Sector threat ; IAG, Ryanair and easyJet face demand for fuller explanation 
on contingency planning
Financial Times (London, England)
November 14, 2018 Wednesday
Edition 1, Asian Edition
Copyright 2018 The Financial Times Limited All Rights Reserved
Section: COMPANIES AND MARKETS;BUSINESS; Pg. 16
Length: 793 words
Byline: JOSH SPERO ;ATTRACTA MOONEY
Body
Investors are stepping up pressure on IAG, Ryanair and easyJet to explain how the airlines are preparing their 
businesses for a no-deal Brexit as fears rise that their aircraft will be grounded.
Shareholders have asked for meetings with airline bosses and board members as the Brexit deadline looms.
There are also growing concerns that UK-based investors might be forced to dump shares in the event of a no-deal 
Brexit or lose voting rights.
One big UK-based investor said: "We are due to see easyJet shortly, and will be pressing for more detail. It affects 
them as much as everyone else.
"They [the airlines] are putting contingency plans in place. It is going to be a major problem if they can't take off or 
land."
Another of the UK's biggest investors said portfolio managers at the asset manager had been pressing for more 
details on how the airlines would cope with a no-deal Brexit.
"It is not a simple question, and you can bet your bottom dollar the answer will be even more complex," he said.
Investors put pressure on airlines as Brexit deadline looms Travel & leisure. Sector threat ; IAG, Ryanair and 
easyJet face demand for fuller explanation on con....
"They are running the business, they are closer to the policymakers. If we got the answer that they weren't worried 
about it, it would raise a warning flag."
The European Commission is planning to give airlines no extra time to meet the EU's ownership requirements, 
according to Brussels' draft contingency plans. Under existing rules, airlines must prove they are 50 per cent EU 
owned and controlled to qualify for operating licences.

EU shareholders to ensure that they reach the 51 per cent threshold.
However, these moves would not go down well with shareholders as they would lose their say on issues from pay 
to the chairman's role.
Paul Lee, a corporate governance expert, said it would be a "terrible result" for UK-based investors if they were to 
lose their right to vote at airlines in the event of a no-deal Brexit.
"If you have shares that don't have voting rights, they are not shares. They are a warrant," he said.
With little time left ahead of Britain's scheduled March 29 exit, IAG remains the most reluctant to provide detailed 
assurances to investors about how it would address a no deal, declining to give guidance about whether, if forced, 
over the long term it would opt to be a British company or an EU one.
A report in Spanish newspaper El País over the weekend said that IAG had made it clear to authorities in Madrid 
that it would remain European.
Brexit throws up particular problems for IAG, as it owns British Airways but also EU-based airlines.
The problems have been compounded by the likelihood that a post-Brexit US-UK aviation agreement will be 
expected to require the Spanish-registered company to be majority-owned by UK parties.
"For traffic rights purposes, [IAG] needs to argue that BA is British to one side of the world, and to the other they 
need to argue that [IAG's other subsidiaries] Iberia, Vueling and Aer Lingus are solidly European," said Andrew 
Lobbenberg, analyst at HSBC.
He said supposing such an outcome could be sustainable after Brexit required "a suspension of disbelief".
To date, IAG has done little more than mention that it has "contingency plans" for Brexit; the response on the issue 
from Antonio Vázquez Romero, IAG chairman. Elsewhere, long-haul lowcost carrier Norwegian has a UK subsidiary 
in the same position as BA regarding the US, as does Virgin Atlantic. Sir Richard Branson owns 51 per cent of 
Virgin, making it majority-UKowned. But he is in the process of selling 31 per cent to Air France-KLM, which could 
complicate Virgin's access rights to the US. US airline Delta owns the remaining stake. In the event of a nodeal 
Brexit, Air France-KLM and Delta have agreed a deal to keep Virgin as the majority shareholder, protecting its US 
flight rights.
Norwegian said: "Structurally, Norwegian is well-positioned to protect our flying rights both in Europe and the UK, 
including in the unlikely event of a nodeal Brexit." Norwegian would use its main airline to keep flying around 
Europe and its UK one to fly to the US, if a UK-US agreement is reached.
In the case of IAG, if there is a no-deal Brexit, it would need to disfranchise non-EU shareholders, taking away 
voting rights, though this might leave BA in an awkward position on its profitable US flights. But even if everything 
went as smoothly as IAG is hoping for, there is no assurance it could maintain its corporate equilibrium indefinitely. 
HSBC's Mr Lobbenberg said: "The requirement that European airlines be controlled and owned by EU citizens is 
there in black and white."

Investors put pressure on airlines as Brexit deadline looms; Travel & leisure. 
Sector threat IAG, Ryanair and easyJet face demand for fuller explanation on 
contingency planning
Financial Times (London, England)
November 14, 2018 Wednesday
Edition 1, National Edition

"It is not a simple question, and you can bet your bottom dollar the answer will be even more complex," he said.

Investors put pressure on airlines as Brexit deadline looms; Travel & leisure. 
Sector threat ; IAG, Ryanair and easyJet face demand for fuller explanation 
on contingency planning
Financial Times (London, England)
November 14, 2018 Wednesday
Edition 1, European Edition
Copyright 2018 The Financial Times Limited All Rights Reserved
Section: COMPANIES AND MARKETS;BUSINESS; Pg. 15
Length: 793 words
Byline: JOSH SPERO ; ATTRACTA MOONEY
Body
Investors are stepping up pressure on IAG, Ryanair and easyJet to explain how the airlines are preparing their 
businesses for a no-deal Brexit as fears rise that their aircraft will be grounded.

easyJet face demand for fuller explanation on con....

about it, it would raise a warning flag."

Lobbenberg, analyst at HSBC.
He said supposing such an outcome could be sustainable after Brexit required "a suspension of disbelief".
To date, IAG has done little more than mention that it has "contingency plans" for Brexit; the response on the issue 
from Antonio Vázquez Romero, IAG chairman. Elsewhere, long-haul lowcost carrier Norwegian has a UK subsidiary 
in the same position as BA regarding the US, as does Virgin Atlantic. Sir Richard Branson owns 51 per cent of 
Virgin, making it majority-UKowned. But he is in the process of selling 31 per cent to Air France-KLM, which could 
complicate Virgin's access rights to the US. US airline Delta owns the remaining stake. In the event of a nodeal 
Brexit, Air France-KLM and Delta have agreed a deal to keep Virgin as the majority shareholder, protecting its US 
flight rights.
Norwegian said: "Structurally, Norwegian is well-positioned to protect our flying rights both in Europe and the UK, 
including in the unlikely event of a nodeal Brexit." Norwegian would use its main airline to keep flying around 
Europe and its UK one to fly to the US, if a UK-US agreement is reached.
In the case of IAG, if there is a no-deal Brexit, it would need to disfranchise non-EU shareholders, taking away 
voting rights, though this might leave BA in an awkward position on its profitable US flights. But even if everything 
went as smoothly as IAG is hoping for, there is no assurance it could maintain its corporate equilibrium indefinitely. 
HSBC's Mr Lobbenberg said: "The requirement that European airlines be controlled and owned by EU citizens is 
there in black and white."
Additional reporting by Alex Barker in Brussels
Investors put pressure on airlines as Brexit deadline looms Travel & leisure. Sector threat ; IAG, Ryanair and 
easyJet face demand for fuller explanation on con....
'We will be pressing for more detail. It is going to be a major problem if they can't take off or land'
Graphic
 
Fasten your seat belts: concerns are mounting that investors based in the UK might be forced to dump shares or 
that they would lose voting rights Daniel Leal-Olivas/AFP/Getty Images

UK skills squeeze poses another Brexit dilemma Government must balance immigration curbs with companies' 
needs
UK skills squeeze poses another Brexit dilemma; Government must balance 
immigration curbs with companies' needs
Financial Times (London, England)
November 13, 2018 Tuesday
Edition 1, National Edition
Copyright 2018 The Financial Times Limited All Rights Reserved
Section: NEWS; Pg. 12
Length: 593 words
Body
There was a particular irony in the recent profit warning from the JD Wetherspoon pub chain, which said it was 
having to increase wages in the face of a tight labour market. Tim Martin, the Wetherspoons chairman, was a 
prominent supporter of Britain's exit from the EU - which is set to make the labour market even tighter.
Mr Martin suggested Wetherspoons would not be further squeezed by Brexit as many of its pubs were in 
lowimmigration towns or rural areas and 90 per cent of its workers were Britishborn. But across the economy, 
competition will only intensify as the government prepares to curb immigration in response to what it sees as one of 
the driving forces behind the Leave victory in the 2016 referendum.
The UK is already at its closest to full employment since the early 1970s, with a 4 per cent jobless rate. Companies 
such as Royal Mail and Ryanair have also warned of wage pressures. A Financial Times report, meanwhile, found 
the hospitality, IT, construction, healthcare and leisure-related services sectors were suffering acute shortages of 
skilled or unskilled workers.
In some ways, rising wages are welcome, after pay increases lagged even the insipid recovery of recent years. 
Real incomes have still to regain their level before the financial crisis of a decade ago. But the tight labour market 
has important implications.
The IT, healthcare and construction sectors are all confronting a shortage of necessary skills. For hospitality and 
industries such as hairdressers and beauticians, where half of staff tend to be under 30, the challenge is different. 
UK skills squeeze poses another Brexit dilemma Government must balance immigration curbs with companies' 
needs
Thanks to a dip in the birth rate around the millennium, one senior hospitality sector representative says the issue is 
simply a "shortage of bodies available". The meat processing industry, with 60 per cent of its staff coming from 
continental Europe, has raised alarms too. By unleashing some pent-up corporate investment, a benign Brexit 
under an agreed deal - though that scenario seems ever more in question - might increase UK economic output by 
1 per cent above current forecasts over, say, three years. But with such meagre growth in productivity over the past 
decade, higher wages are likely to be passed on quickly to consumers, resulting in inflationary pressures. Interest 
rate rises from the Bank of England would then be likely to snuff out much of this growth. A tighter jobs market 
makes growth even more likely to be inflationary.
The government needs, therefore, to strike a careful balance between the urge to staunch immigration, and 
businesses' need for staff. Its Migration Advisory Committee recommended scrapping a 20,700-a-year cap on "Tier 
2" visas for high-skilled workers, to ensure companies can attract talent. But it suggested limiting low-skilled 
migration, except in agriculture.
The Home Office, due to publish an immigration white paper in coming weeks, has indicated it might reject some 
MAC recommendations. It should consider sector-specific visa schemes allowing critical industries such as food 
processing to bring in non-UK workers for a defined period.
Over the longer term, the answer must be, in part, investment in education and re-training to match the needs of 
British employers. Even if it can navigate its way successfully through Brexit, however, the government will face a 
continuing dilemma. The 2016 vote put it under pressure to close doors to migrants. Yet even a modest Brexit 
dividend - one that recouped some of the growth lost since the referendum - could be partially dissipated if there are 
not enough workers to deliver it.
Load-Date: November 12, 2018
End of Document

Boeing Delivers 625 Aircraft Through October
Boeing Delivers 625 Aircraft Through October
MT Newswires Live Briefs
November 13, 2018 Tuesday 1:46 PM EST
Copyright 2018 MT Newswires All Rights Reserved
Length: 82 words
Body
 Boeing (BA) has delivered 625 aircraft this year through October, 450 of which are the 737, according to figures on 
its official website.
The company has delivered the most number of aircraft this year to Ryanair (RYAAY) with 45 737's, followed by 
Southwest Airlines (LUV) with 39 737's and China Eastern Airlines (CEA) with 26 737's and four 787's.
Boeing has also received 642 net orders this year through October, 453 of which are for the 737.

Comgest Global Investors S.A.S. Sells 25,300 Shares of Ryanair Holdings plc ( RYAAY )
Comgest Global Investors S.A.S. Sells 25,300 Shares of Ryanair Holdings plc 
(RYAAY)
American Banking and Market News
November 12, 2018 Monday
Copyright 2018 American Banking and Market News All Rights Reserved
Length: 635 words
Body
Ryanair logo Comgest Global Investors S.A.S. cut its position in shares of  Ryanair Holdings plc (NASDAQ:RYAAY) 
by 35.2% in the third quarter, according to its most recent 13F filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission 
(SEC). The institutional investor  owned 46,500 shares of the transportation company's stock after selling 25,300 
shares during the period. Comgest Global Investors S.A.S.'s holdings in Ryanair were worth $4,466,000 as of its 
most recent SEC filing.  
Several other institutional investors and hedge funds have also recently bought and sold shares of the company. 
Voya Investment Management LLC raised its stake in shares of  Ryanair by 35.2% in the 2nd quarter. Voya 
Investment Management LLC now owns 2,975 shares of the transportation company's stock valued at $340,000 
after acquiring an additional 775 shares in the last quarter.  Comerica Bank raised its stake in shares of  Ryanair by 
6.7% in the 3rd quarter. Comerica Bank now owns 16,139 shares of the transportation company's stock valued at 
$1,343,000 after acquiring an additional 1,008 shares in the last quarter.  First Mercantile Trust Co. raised its stake 
in shares of  Ryanair by 28.8% in the 2nd quarter. First Mercantile Trust Co. now owns 6,135 shares of the 
transportation company's stock valued at $701,000 after acquiring an additional 1,370 shares in the last quarter.  
Mitchell Capital Management Co. raised its stake in shares of  Ryanair by 38.6% in the 2nd quarter. Mitchell Capital 
Management Co. now owns 4,996 shares of the transportation company's stock valued at $571,000 after acquiring 
an additional 1,392 shares in the last quarter.  Finally, First Republic Investment Management Inc. raised its stake 
in shares of  Ryanair by 16.4% in the 2nd quarter. First Republic Investment Management Inc. now owns 12,111 
shares of the transportation company's stock valued at $1,384,000 after acquiring an additional 1,705 shares in the 
last quarter. 44.02% of the stock is owned by institutional investors.  
RYAAY has been the topic of several recent analyst reports. Royal Bank of Canada  reaffirmed a "buy" rating on 
shares of Ryanair in a research report on Thursday, August 16th. UBS Group  reaffirmed a "buy" rating on shares 
of Ryanair in a research report on Wednesday, August 15th. ValuEngine  raised Ryanair from a "sell" rating to a 
"hold" rating in a research report on Monday, September 17th. BidaskClub raised Ryanair from a "sell" rating to a 
"hold" rating in a research report on Tuesday, October 9th. Finally, Raymond James downgraded Ryanair from an 
"outperform" rating to a "market perform" rating in a research report on Thursday, August 9th. Two investment 
analysts have rated the stock with a sell rating, seven have given a hold rating and three have assigned  a buy 
rating to the company. The stock  has a consensus rating of "Hold" and an average target price of $138.00. 
Comgest Global Investors S.A.S. Sells 25,300 Shares of Ryanair Holdings plc ( RYAAY )
Shares of NASDAQ:RYAAY  opened at $88.14 on Monday. Ryanair Holdings plc has a 1-year low of $77.96 and a 
1-year high of $127.61. The company has a market cap of $20.68 billion, a PE ratio of 12.50 and a beta of 0.74. 
The company has a current ratio of 1.25, a quick ratio of 1.25 and a debt-to-equity ratio of 0.62.   
Ryanair Company Profile
Ryanair Holdings plc, together with its subsidiaries, provides scheduled-passenger airline services in Ireland, the 
United Kingdom, and Other European countries. The company is also involved in the provision of various ancillary 
services, such as non-flight scheduled services and Internet-related services; in-flight sale of beverages, food, and 
merchandise; and marketing accommodation services, holidays, car hire, and travel insurance through its Website.

Former boss to take on Stobart in court battle
Former boss to take on Stobart in court battle
City A.M.
November 12, 2018 Monday
Edition 1, National Edition
Copyright 2018 City A.M. All Rights Reserved
Section: NEWS; Pg. 8
Length: 319 words
Byline: CALLUM KEOWN
Body
THE BITTER boardroom battle between Stobart and a former company boss will come to a head this morning as 
the trial into the dismissal of Andrew Tinkler gets under way.
The Southend Airport owner claims Tinkler led an unlawful conspiracy against the company with an unsuccessful 
attempt to topple chairman Iain Ferguson in July.
Tinkler supported Edinburgh Woollen Mill owner Philip Day for the role, but he was narrowly defeated in a 
shareholders' vote.
But Tinkler, who was chief executive for a decade, has lodged a counterclaim that his dismissal was invalid. 
Tinkler's lawyers amended their argument at a pre-trial hearing last month to include claims that the "difficult 
questions" he asked regarding Stobart's deal with Ryanair partly led to his dismissal.
At the annual meeting just days before his dismissal, he suggested the company''s $300m (£225m) deal, which will 
see three Ryanair aircraft based at the airport from next summer, would negatively impact its finances.
Tinkler's legal team will also argue that the chairman vote was swayed after chief executive Warwick Brady and 
Ferguson decided over Whatsapp to transfer 6m treasury shares to Employment Benefit Trust shares and use them 
to vote for Ferguson.
Stobart will claim Tinkler had made decisions regarding the failed takeover of Flybe to "enrich himself".
The firm will also claim he conspired with shareholders to elect billionaire entrepreneur Philip Day as chairman, 
creating a cabal which misused confidential information and "destabilised" the company.
Former boss to take on Stobart in court battle
In a separate matter, Stobart will claim Tinkler further breached his fiduciary duties through "excessive and 
unnecessary" expenses.
At a pre-trial hearing last month the court heard Tinkler's daughter had been using a company flat in Soho Square 
and Range Rover acquired at a charity event and that he had used Stobart funds for his helicopter and jet travel. 
Tinkler denies the allegations.
Load-Date: November 12, 2018
End of Document
Ryanair Holdings plc ( RYAAY ) Receives Average Rating of "Hold" from Analysts
Ryanair Holdings plc (RYAAY) Receives Average Rating of "Hold" from 
Analysts
American Banking and Market News
November 11, 2018 Sunday
Copyright 2018 American Banking and Market News All Rights Reserved
Length: 566 words
Body
Ryanair logo Shares of Ryanair Holdings plc (NASDAQ:RYAAY) have been given an average rating of "Hold" by 
the twelve research firms that are currently  covering the company,            MarketBeat Ratings  reports. Two 
equities research analysts have rated the stock with a sell rating, seven have assigned  a hold rating and three 
have issued  a buy rating on  the company. 
A number of equities research analysts have recently commented on RYAAY shares. BidaskClub lowered shares of 
Ryanair from a "sell" rating to a "strong sell" rating in a research note on Thursday, September 13th. Royal Bank of 
Canada  reaffirmed a "buy" rating on shares of Ryanair in a research note on Thursday, August 16th. ValuEngine  
raised shares of Ryanair from a "strong sell" rating to a "sell" rating in a research note on Tuesday, October 16th. 
UBS Group  reissued a "buy" rating on shares of Ryanair in a research note on Wednesday, August 15th. Finally, 
Raymond James lowered shares of Ryanair from an "outperform" rating to a "market perform" rating in a research 
note on Thursday, August 9th. 
A number of hedge funds and other institutional investors have recently modified their holdings of RYAAY. 
Massachusetts Financial Services Co. MA raised its holdings in  Ryanair by 14.5% during the second quarter. 
Massachusetts Financial Services Co. MA now owns 2,539,197 shares of the transportation company's stock worth 
$290,053,000 after buying an additional 321,859 shares during the last quarter.  WCM Investment Management CA 
raised its holdings in  Ryanair by 7.6% during the third quarter. WCM Investment Management CA now owns

shares during the last quarter.  JPMorgan Chase & Co. raised its holdings in  Ryanair by 17.3% during the third

$190,487,000 after buying an additional 293,233 shares during the last quarter.  Commonwealth of Pennsylvania

now owns 5,936,962 shares of the transportation company's stock worth $678,179,000 after buying an additional 
133,294 shares during the last quarter. 44.02% of the stock is currently owned by institutional investors and hedge 
funds.

Ryanair Holdings plc ( RYAAY ) Receives Average Rating of "Hold" from Analysts
About Ryanair
Ryanair Holdings plc, together with its subsidiaries, provides scheduled-passenger airline services in Ireland, the 
United Kingdom, and Other European countries. The company is also involved in the provision of various ancillary 
services, such as non-flight scheduled services and Internet-related services; in-flight sale of beverages, food, and 
merchandise; and marketing accommodation services, holidays, car hire, and travel insurance through its Website.

France seizes jet at takeoff after Ryanair doesn't pay bill
France seizes jet at takeoff after Ryanair doesn't pay bill
Associated Press Financial Wire
November 10, 2018 Saturday 1:29 AM GMT
Copyright 2018 Associated Press All Rights Reserved
Section: BUSINESS NEWS
Length: 528 words
Byline: By ANGELA CHARLTON and CARLO PIOVANO, Associated Press
Dateline: PARIS 
Body
PARIS (AP) - Storms, strikes, computer failures - you can now add "your plane has been seized by the 
government" to the list of things that can delay your flight.
In France, 149 passengers were preparing to take off for London late Thursday when French authorities ordered 
their Ryanair Boeing 737 impounded.
The budget carrier owed money and it was "regrettable that the state was forced" to evacuate the plane, the civil 
aviation authority said.
The passengers had gone through passport control and security and were about to walk on the tarmac to board the 
plane when airport authorities told them to turn around, passenger Boris Hejblum said.
"The airport staff told us there was an issue with the plane," he told The Associated Press in an email.
No Ryanair staff members were available, and the only communication from the airline was two text messages 
saying simply that the departure was delayed, and a 5-euro ($5.75) voucher for food - "less than what a sandwich 
cost at the airport café," the 30-year-old Frenchman said.
"I found it strange that the police were the only ones giving us information," he said.
The passengers were put on another flight that finally brought them to London's Stansted airport - five hours late.
The multi-million dollar jet, meanwhile, was released only Friday after Ryanair paid a bill of 525,000 euros 
($610,000).
The scene unfolded at the Bordeaux-Merignac airport in western France, where authorities say the airline was 
ordered to pay back funds that the European Union had declared to be illegal subsidies. Ryanair did not publicly 
comment on the seizure.
France seizes jet at takeoff after Ryanair doesn't pay bill
French aviation agency spokesman Eric Heraud said regional authorities who originally gave the subsidies had 
been trying since 2014 to recover the money, and sent its final legal warning in May. After six months without a 
response from Ryanair, it decided to act Friday.
The standoff with French authorities will not help Ryanair, which more than most carriers, has come to symbolize 
budget airlines' relentless focus on the bottom line at the cost of customer service.
Ryanair has become Europe's largest airline by number of passengers by persistently offering some of the 
cheapest fares available. That ensures its planes are packed.
It then makes extra money with add-on fares. Besides charging for seating choice and food - now standard practice 
on budget flights the world over - it also has travelers pay for any carry-on bag that's larger than a purse.
It manages to keep its costs down by flying to out of the way airports at odd hours to get cheaper airport slots.
Its CEO, Michael O'Leary, personifies the airline's brash approach, sparring with unions and EU authorities. And 
despite conceding in 2013 that "we should try to eliminate things that unnecessarily piss people off," the airline 
retains its reputation as something to be endured for the sake of flying cheaply around Europe.
"I would say we just took it as another Ryanair problem, having no information from them," Hejblum said of 
Thursday's incident. "When we found out about the seizure, I would say the general sentiment was to blame 
Ryanair for not complying with the law."
___
Piovano reported from London.
Load-Date: November 10, 2018
End of Document
Russell Investments Group Ltd. Buys 11,533 Shares of Ryanair Holdings plc ( RYAAY )
Russell Investments Group Ltd. Buys 11,533 Shares of Ryanair Holdings plc 
(RYAAY)
American Banking and Market News
November 10, 2018 Saturday
Copyright 2018 American Banking and Market News All Rights Reserved
Length: 606 words
Body
Ryanair logo Russell Investments Group Ltd. boosted its stake in shares of  Ryanair Holdings plc 
(NASDAQ:RYAAY) by 7.0% in the third quarter, according to its most recent 13F filing with the Securities and 
Exchange Commission. The firm owned 176,550 shares of the transportation company's stock after acquiring an 
additional 11,533 shares during the quarter. Russell Investments Group Ltd. owned about 0.08% of Ryanair worth 
$17,039,000 as of its most recent filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission.  
Other institutional investors also recently bought and sold shares of the company. Voya Investment Management 
LLC lifted its position in  Ryanair by 35.2% during the 2nd quarter. Voya Investment Management LLC now owns 
2,975 shares of the transportation company's stock worth $340,000 after acquiring an additional 775 shares during 
the period.  Jane Street Group LLC acquired a new stake in  Ryanair during the 2nd quarter worth approximately 
$371,000.  Lucia Wealth Services LLC acquired a new stake in shares of  Ryanair in the 2nd quarter valued at 
approximately $408,000.  Tower Research Capital LLC TRC lifted its holdings in shares of  Ryanair by 94.6% in the 
2nd quarter. Tower Research Capital LLC TRC now owns 3,645 shares of the transportation company's stock 
valued at $416,000 after buying an additional 1,772 shares during the period.  Finally, Mitchell Capital Management 
Co. lifted its holdings in shares of  Ryanair by 38.6% in the 2nd quarter. Mitchell Capital Management Co. now 
owns 4,996 shares of the transportation company's stock valued at $571,000 after buying an additional 1,392 
shares during the period. 44.02% of the stock is owned by institutional investors.  
RYAAY  opened at $88.14 on Friday. The company has a quick ratio of 1.25, a current ratio of 1.25 and a debt-to-
equity ratio of 0.62. The company has a market capitalization of $20.72 billion, a PE ratio of 12.90 and a beta of 
0.74. Ryanair Holdings plc has a 12 month low of $77.96 and a 12 month high of $127.61.  
Several analysts have recently commented on the company. ValuEngine  cut Ryanair from a "sell" rating to a 
"strong sell" rating in a report on Tuesday, October 2nd. Raymond James cut Ryanair from an "outperform" rating to 
a "market perform" rating in a report on Thursday, August 9th. BidaskClub raised Ryanair from a "sell" rating to a 
"hold" rating in a report on Tuesday, October 9th. UBS Group  reissued a "buy" rating on shares of Ryanair in a 
report on Wednesday, August 15th. Finally, Royal Bank of Canada  reissued a "buy" rating on shares of Ryanair in 
a report on Thursday, August 16th. Two equities research analysts have rated the stock with a sell rating, seven 
have assigned  a hold rating and three have assigned  a buy rating to the company's stock. The stock currently has 
a consensus rating of "Hold" and an average price target of $138.00.  
Ryanair Profile
Russell Investments Group Ltd. Buys 11,533 Shares of Ryanair Holdings plc ( RYAAY )
Ryanair Holdings plc, together with its subsidiaries, provides scheduled-passenger airline services in Ireland, the 
United Kingdom, and Other European countries. The company is also involved in the provision of various ancillary 
services, such as non-flight scheduled services and Internet-related services; in-flight sale of beverages, food, and 
merchandise; and marketing accommodation services, holidays, car hire, and travel insurance through its Website.

Ryanair pays France (EURO)525,000 for impounded jet Airlines ; Low-cost carrier forced to repay regional 
subsidies deemed illegal by Brussels
Ryanair pays France (EURO)525,000 for impounded jet; Airlines ; Low-cost 
carrier forced to repay regional subsidies deemed illegal by Brussels
Financial Times (London, England)
November 10, 2018 Saturday
Edition 1, National Edition
Copyright 2018 The Financial Times Limited All Rights Reserved
Section: NEWS; Pg. 19
Length: 453 words
Byline: ARTHUR BEESLEY
Body
Ryanair faced yet more woe as the lowcost airline was forced to pay (EURO)525,000 to France yesterday to secure 
the return of a jet impounded at Bordeaux airport.
The Irish company, which has faced months of bad publicity over flight disruptions and strikes, made the payment 
after almost 150 passengers were taken off a London-bound plane by the French Civil Aviation Authority.
France said the jet was seized as a "last resort" in a dispute over the repayment of regional funding for flights at the 
Angoulême airport that were later deemed illegal by Brussels.
The Associated Press cited Eric Heraud, spokesman for the French Civil Aviation Authority, saying the plane would 
be released after Ryanair paid back the funds.
The European Commission's ruling was one of seven findings of illegal state aid between 2014 and 2016 against 
Ryanair's arrangements at regional airports that included Nîmes, Altenburg, Zweibrücken, Cagliari and Klagenfurt. 
The airline appealed in the European courts when it was ordered to repay some (EURO)23.7m of alleged aid after it 
was ruled to have gained an unfair economic advantage.
Ryanair pays France (EURO)525,000 for impounded jet Airlines ; Low-cost carrier forced to repay regional 
subsidies deemed illegal by Brussels
The French authority said: "It is unfortunate that the state had to take such action, which led to the inevitable 
inconvenience of the 149 passengers on board the immobilised plane." It added: "Those passengers were able to 
eventually reach their destination later that evening on another Ryanair plane, but with a five-hour delay."
Ryanair did not respond to a request for comments.
The company faces more pressure from competition regulators. In October the European Commission opened an 
inquiry into whether Ryanair benefited from illegal state aid at Germany's Frankfurt-Hahn airport.
In recent days Italy's antitrust agency opened a probe against Ryanair's new hand luggage policies.
The dispute over the grounded jet comes during a period of turbulence at the airline that kicked off last year when a 
rostering "mess-up" led to thousands of flights being cancelled.
This week the company sacked six cabin crew who were pictured sleeping on the floor of a Spanish airport office. 
Ryanair said the image, widely shared online, was staged.
The development came as Ryanair and Michael O'Leary, its longtime chief executive, were sued in New York by a 
shareholder claiming the airline defrauded investors and inflated its share price by overstating its ability to manage 
labour relations and keep costs down. Ryanair said such claims were "false" and "doomed to fail".
In addition, lawyers representing an elderly woman racially abused on a flight have demanded compensation and 
asked the airline for a "proper" apology. There was outrage last month when a passenger was filmed hurling verbal 
abuse at the woman.
Load-Date: November 9, 2018
End of Document

Saturday Papers: Brent crude enters bear market at below $70
Saturday Papers: Brent crude enters bear market at below $70
Citywire
November 10, 2018 Saturday 7:00 AM GMT
Copyright 2018 Citywire Financial Publishers All Rights Reserved
Length: 666 words
Byline: Himanshu Singh
Highlight: And GDP growth hits highest level since 2016 but economists warn growth spurt will be 'flash in the 
pan'.
Body
Top stories
•
Financial Times: Brent crude fell below $70 a barrel on Friday as a result of American efforts to drive down 
the price of oil by pressuring its Gulf allies to ramp up production.
•
The Daily Telegraph: GDP growth hit its highest level since 2016 in the third quarter but the crucial 
services sector slid into contraction territory in September as the economy starts to lose its momentum.
•
The Times: UK Transport Minister Jo Johnson resigned last night, declaring Theresa May’s approach to 
Brexit a failure on a scale not seen since Suez.
•
Financial Times: Shares in General Electric tumbled 10% following a negative comment from an analyst 
from JP Morgan, prompting the American conglomerate to issue statement to reassure investors about its 
financial health.
•
Financial Times: Former Goldman Sachs partner Tim Leissner, who pleaded guilty to crimes in connection 
to the 1MDB scandal, claimed concealing facts from internal compliance officials was the culture at the 
bank.
•
Financial Times: US regulators are planning to ban most flavoured versions of the product in shops and 
petrol stations across the country, in a response to concerns that teenage vaping has reached “epidemic” 
levels.
Business and economics
•
Financial Times: Apple has nearly tripled the amount of land it owns over the past two years, purchasing 
lands across US to build data centres and solar farms that can also help secure lucrative tax breaks.
•
The Times: Informa, which acquired UBM in June, reported a 3.9% rise in underlying revenues for the first 
ten months of the year.
•
Financial Times: Ryanair was forced to pay €525,000 to France on Friday to secure the return of a jet 
impounded at Bordeaux airport in a dispute over the repayment of regional funding for flights at the 
Angoulême airport.
Saturday Papers: Brent crude enters bear market at below $70
•
Financial Times: Richemont shares plunged on Friday after the Swiss luxury goods group signalled that 
sales growth had stalled in September.
•
Financial Times: ThyssenKrupp shares fell more than 10% on Friday after the beleaguered steel and 
elevators conglomerate issued its second profit warning this year.
•
The Daily Telegraph: Rolls-Royce’s reputation for reliability was further damaged after the engineer warned 
of fresh problems affecting around 200 of its engines.
•
Financial Times: Coast Capital Management, a top-10 shareholder in UK transport business FirstGroup, 
has called for the company’s board to step down and said its UK rail arm is “extraordinarily destructive” of 
capital.
•
The Times: London-listed mobile app maker Mysquar has warned investors that nearly £1 million raised 
from the sale of bonds has gone missing after an investigation that led to the suspension of its shares this 
week.
•
The Daily Telegraph: Richard Branson-backed transport company Virgin Hyperloop One has laid off 
dozens of staff including top executives as it fights for its future.
•
The Guardian: Construction of the controversial Keystone XL pipeline has been halted after a court ruling 
that the Trump administration didn’t properly consider the environmental consequences before pushing 
ahead with the enormous oil project.
•
The Daily Telegraph: MPs have asked the National Audit Office to open an investigation into the 
Government’s £350 million bailout of the delayed Crossrail project.
•
Daily Mail: Some of Britain's biggest supermarkets have won a long-running £400 million court battle over 
having to pay separate business rates on cash machines.
•
The Daily Telegraph: Fastjet has warned again that it is on the brink of collapse unless it can raise more 
money or reach an agreement with key creditors in the coming days.
Share tips, comment and bids
•
The Daily Telegraph (Questor share tips): HOLD Gama Aviation; HOLD Michelmersh.
•
The Daily Telegraph: BT Group has roped in Lazard to sell its fleet management division, which is 
estimated to be worth in excess of £200 million.
•
The Times: AO World has acquired Mobile Phones Direct as it seeks to expand its business.
•
The Guardian (Comment): Philip Hammond claims strong growth, but it's mostly froth.

Ryanair pays up after France impounds plane just before takeoff
Ryanair pays up after France impounds plane just before takeoff
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
November 9, 2018 Friday 4:46 PM GMT
Copyright 2018 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 220 words
Byline: Pol O Gradaigh in Paris
Dateline: Paris (dpa) - 
Body
Budget airline Ryanair paid French authorities 525,000 euros (596,000 dollars) Friday to release a plane seized at 
Bordeaux Airport the day before, the country's aviation authorities said.
The Irish carrier's climbdown came too late for the 149 passengers who had been forced to disembark from their 
Thursday afternoon flight to London when the jet was impounded on the tarmac.
France's civil aviation directorate earlier said it was "regrettable" the plane had to be impounded "as a last resort" in 
order to recoup state aid to Ryanair that the European Union had ruled was illegal.
The passengers experienced a five-hour delay but made it to their destination with a later Ryanair flight, the 
directorate said.
In 2014, the European Commission said Ryanair had to repay 858,000 euros' (973,000 dollars') worth of rebates 
and marketing arrangements it received at Angouleme airport, not far from Bordeaux.
The EU at the time also ordered authorities to recoup money from Ryanair and Transavia over benefits they had 
received at two other French regional airports.
Ryanair did not respond to a request for comment. The plane was released back to the airline at about 12:30 pm 
(1130 GMT) after the payment was received, authorities said.
Editorial contactsEditing by: Miranda Lee Murray, +49 30 2852 31472, <international@dpa.com;
Load-Date: November 10, 2018
Ryanair pays up after France impounds plane just before takeoff
End of Document
France seizes jet at takeoff after Ryanair doesn't pay bill
France seizes jet at takeoff after Ryanair doesn't pay bill
American Banking and Market News
November 9, 2018 Friday
Copyright 2018 American Banking and Market News All Rights Reserved
Length: 575 words
Body
PARIS (AP) â€” Storms, strikes, computer failures â€” you can now add "your plane has been seized by the 
government" to the list of things that can delay your flight.               
In France, 149 passengers were preparing to take off for London late Thursday when French authorities ordered 
their Ryanair Boeing 737 impounded.               
The budget carrier owed money and it was "regrettable that the state was forced" to evacuate the plane, the civil 
aviation authority said.               
The passengers had gone through passport control and security and were about to walk on the tarmac to board the 
plane when airport authorities told them to turn around, passenger Boris Hejblum said.               
"The airport staff told us there was an issue with the plane," he told The Associated Press in an email.               
No Ryanair staff members were available, and the only communication from the airline was two text messages 
saying simply that the departure was delayed, and a 5-euro ($5.75) voucher for food â€” "less than what a 
sandwich cost at the airport café," the 30-year-old Frenchman said.               
"I found it strange that the police were the only ones giving us information," he said.               
The passengers were put on another flight that finally brought them to London's Stansted airport â€” five hours late.               
The multi-million dollar jet, meanwhile, was released only Friday after Ryanair paid a bill of 525,000 euros 
($610,000).               
The scene unfolded at the Bordeaux-Merignac airport in western France, where authorities say the airline was 
ordered to pay back funds that the European Union had declared to be illegal subsidies. Ryanair did not publicly 
comment on the seizure.               
French aviation agency spokesman Eric Heraud said regional authorities who originally gave the subsidies had 
been trying since 2014 to recover the money, and sent its final legal warning in May. After six months without a 
response from Ryanair, it decided to act Friday.               
The standoff with French authorities will not help Ryanair, which more than most carriers, has come to symbolize 
budget airlines' relentless focus on the bottom line at the cost of customer service.               
France seizes jet at takeoff after Ryanair doesn't pay bill
Ryanair has become Europe's largest airline by number of passengers by persistently offering some of the 
cheapest fares available. That ensures its planes are packed.               
It then makes extra money with add-on fares. Besides charging for seating choice and food â€” now standard 
practice on budget flights the world over â€” it also has travelers pay for any carry-on bag that's larger than a purse.               
It manages to keep its costs down by flying to out of the way airports at odd hours to get cheaper airport slots.               
Its CEO, Michael O'Leary, personifies the airline's brash approach, sparring with unions and EU authorities. And 
despite conceding in 2013 that "we should try to eliminate things that unnecessarily piss people off," the airline 
retains its reputation as something to be endured for the sake of flying cheaply around Europe.               
"I would say we just took it as another Ryanair problem, having no information from them," Hejblum said of 
Thursday's incident. "When we found out about the seizure, I would say the general sentiment was to blame 
Ryanair for not complying with the law."               
___               
Piovano reported from London.

End of Document

Ryanair (RYAAY) Receives Daily Media Impact Score of 0.33

Ryanair logo News stories about Ryanair (NASDAQ:RYAAY) have trended neutral recently, according to InfoTrie. 
The research firm identifies positive and negative news coverage by reviewing more than six thousand blog and 
news sources. The firm ranks coverage of publicly-traded companies on a scale of negative five to five, with scores 
closest to five being the most favorable. Ryanair earned a media sentiment score of 0.33 on their scale. InfoTrie 
also assigned media coverage about the transportation company an news buzz score of 10 out of 10, indicating that 
recent news coverage is extremely likely to have an effect on the stock's share price in the next several days.

A number of research analysts recently commented on the stock. BidaskClub upgraded shares of Ryanair from a 
"sell" rating to a "hold" rating in a research note on Tuesday, October 9th. UBS Group  reiterated a "buy" rating on 
shares of Ryanair in a research note on Wednesday, August 15th. Raymond James lowered shares of Ryanair from 
an "outperform" rating to a "market perform" rating in a research note on Thursday, August 9th. ValuEngine  
upgraded shares of Ryanair from a "sell" rating to a "hold" rating in a research note on Monday, September 17th. 
Finally, Royal Bank of Canada  restated a "buy" rating on shares of Ryanair in a research report on Thursday, 
August 16th. Two investment analysts have rated the stock with a sell rating, seven have issued  a hold rating and 
three have given a buy rating to the company's stock. The stock  has an average rating of "Hold" and an average 
target price of $138.00. 
Ryanair stock  traded down $0.16 during mid-day trading on Friday, hitting $88.14. The company's stock had a 
trading volume of 262,909 shares, compared to its average volume of 783,220. The company has a debt-to-equity 
ratio of 0.62, a quick ratio of 1.25 and a current ratio of 1.25. The firm has a market cap of $19.93 billion, a price-to-
earnings ratio of 12.50 and a beta of 0.74. Ryanair has a twelve month low of $77.96 and a twelve month high of 
$127.61.   
About Ryanair
Ryanair (RYAAY) Receives Daily Media Impact Score of 0.33
Ryanair Holdings plc, together with its subsidiaries, provides scheduled-passenger airline services in Ireland, the 
United Kingdom, and Other European countries. The company is also involved in the provision of various ancillary 
services, such as non-flight scheduled services and Internet-related services; in-flight sale of beverages, food, and 
merchandise; and marketing accommodation services, holidays, car hire, and travel insurance through its Website.

Airline Passenger Launches Racist, Homophobic Attack On Man After Threatening Flight Attendant
Airline Passenger Launches Racist, Homophobic Attack On Man After 
Threatening Flight Attendant
International Business Times News
November 9, 2018 Friday 9:46 AM EST
Copyright 2018 Newstex LLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 573 words
Body
Nov 09, 2018( International Business Times News: http://www.ibtimes.com Delivered by Newstex)  A female airline 
passenger was caught on camera hurling abusive, racist and homophobic attack on a man sitting near her on a 
plane. The shocking video, which was obtained by the Sun and Mirror Online, showed the woman shouting and 
swearing in front of young children. It remains unclear what triggered the woman to launch the angry tirade at her 
co-passenger as theplane prepared to land at Los Angeles International Airport. 
The airline in which the incident took place was also not mentioned by those who shared the video on social media. 
According to reports, the woman shouted at fellow passengers and crew members for "about an hour."The 
passenger was also said to have 'threatened a flight attendant' shortly before the plane landed. In the video, she 
can be heard saying: "You're a gay-looking a--- n-----" and "you're a white skin a--- n------." When she was asked to 
watch her language because of the young child nearby, she continued to shout. She can be heard repeating: 
"That's not my kid, I don't give a f--k," before adding: "Shut your f------king mouth, it's got nothing to do with you." At 
one point the woman stood up, leaning across the seat, getting closer and closer to the man, telling him: "Stop 
talking s--- and do something." The clip also reportedly shows a flight attendant trying to calm the woman while a 
passenger tells her to 'chill.' The video was taken on Nov. 2, the Sun[1] reported. A passenger who took the footage 
said: "Shortly before this video was filmed she threatened a flight attendant who appeared to come up and try to 
calm here after other attendants had been unsuccessful...That flight attendant called for ground control and I 
assume the police who did end up escorting her off the flight once we landed." He added: "She used racially tinged 
language and homophobic slurs on flight personnel as well as passengers." A view inside a Boeing 787 Dreamliner 
aircraft at the Vienna airport, Dec. 17, 2012. Photo: REUTERS/Heinz-Peter Bader This comes weeks after another 
incident which took place on board a Ryanair flight when a male passengersubjected a fellow passenger to a racist 
tirade. Delsie Gayle became the target of the tirade of abuse by a fellow passenger on flight FR015 from Barcelona, 
Spain, to London Stansted in mid-October. A video of the incident showsa man shouting at Gayle, telling her to 
move seats, while her daughter tries to stand up to him, telling him her mother is disabled. 'I don't care whether 
she's fucking disabled or not - if I tell her to get out, she gets out,' the man can be heard saying,calling the woman 
an 'ugly black b-------.'When Gayle remonstrates with him he shouts at her: 'Don't talk to me in a foreign language, 
you stupid ugly cow.' Describing her shock,the 77-year-oldtold ITV News[2]:'I feel very low. He paid a fare to go on 
holiday, I've paid mine, so why does he abuse me for that due to the colour of my skin? He do it with me and he 
gets away, he'll do it to somebody else.' Later, the man -- identified asDavid Mesher -- claimed thathe is not a racist 
and 
lost 
his 
temper 
'a 
bit.' 
He 
also 
apologized 
for 
the 
incident.

Watch: Ryanair Passenger Avoids Carry-On Baggage Fees By Sewing Clothes Into Coat
Watch: Ryanair Passenger Avoids Carry-On Baggage Fees By Sewing 
Clothes Into Coat
International Business Times News
November 9, 2018 Friday 11:46 AM EST
Copyright 2018 Newstex LLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 681 words
Body
Nov 09, 2018( International Business Times News: http://www.ibtimes.com Delivered by Newstex)  A Staffordshire, 
England, man who grew frustrated with the extreme, new baggage policies of Ireland-based Ryanair, sewed his 
clothes into acoat to avoid the fees for carry-on bags, reports said Thursday. According to the new policies, which 
was revamped for the second time this year, passengers were only allowed one small bag, which must fit below the 
seat in front of them, free of charge. The new policy, announced in August, came into effect from Nov. 
1. Lee Cimino, 30, booked a ticket to Belfast,Northern Ireland, for his birthday through Ryanair two days before the 
new fee was put into place. With the new rule in place, he would have had to pay up to $11 for a large carry-on 
bag.However, Cimino figured out a hack to carry his clothes on board without having to pay the extra baggage fee. 
So instead of packing his rollaway suitcase, he sewed on every article of clothing he needed into a giant and bulky 
coat he could wear on the plane.Cimino found himself a tailor who helped him create pockets using his clothes,and 
then stuffed them with the rest of his clothing, toiletries and every other article he would require during the travel. He 
shared his whole experience in a video posted on Facebook[1] with the caption: 'This is for you if you've ever been 
frustrated by Ryanair. This is how you get around the new baggage charges every time. It might even make you 
smile.' Cimino said he was at first unsure if the idea would work since the coat was quite bulky and obvious, 
reported Fox News[2]. But, as seen in the video, he made it to Belfast with his coat/suitcase intact. [embedded 
content] 'I fly with Ryanair all over, so I'm clued up when it comes to their bag rules. It's not breaking any rules to try 
and take all of your luggage in your clothes, so I took an old coat out of my cupboard and took it to Sew Wot Tailors 
in Tunstall to see what they could do for around [$33-$39],' he said according to a report on the New York Post.[3] 
'There was no scene created because we weren't trying to make a scene, we just wanted to do it in a discreet 
manner to see if we could and to prove that you could get onto the plane still carrying what you needed,' Cimino 
said. Reports said Cimino intended to auction his coat and give half of the profit to a charity of Ryanair's choice. A 
Ryanair passenger sewed clothes on to his coat to avoid paying carry-on baggage charges. In this image: A man 
pulling a suitcase walks past a billboard advertisement for Ryanair during a 24-hour strike by its pilots in 
Schoenefeld, Germany, Aug. 10, 2018. Photo: Getty Images/Sean Gallup Previously, Ryanair passengers were 
allowed to carry one bigger bag, tagged at the gate and put in the plane's hold, with them for free. However, only 
passengers who purchase priority boarding will be able to check in their larger bags for free. According to the 
airline's website[4], priority boarding plus two cabin bags charges start at an extra 6 (about $7.74) per ticket. At the 
same time, the airline has changed its definition of a small bag from 13.7'' x 7.8'' x 7.8'' to 16.4''x 7.8'' x 11.8''. 'This 
new policy will speed up the boarding and cut flight delays,' Kenny Jacobs, Ryanair's chief marketing officer, said 
according to a report on Travel + Leisure[5]. '60% of customers will be unaffected by these changes and we expect 
Watch: Ryanair Passenger Avoids Carry-On Baggage Fees By Sewing Clothes Into Coat
that the other 40% will either choose to buy Priority Boarding or a 10kg check bag or will choose to travel with only 
one 
(free) 
small 
bag 
as 
30% 
already 
do 
so 
today.'
