Ryanair introduces new hand luggage rules amid competition concerns
Ryanair introduces new hand luggage rules amid competition concerns
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
November 1, 2018 Thursday 11:40 AM GMT
Copyright 2018 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 267 words
Byline: Femke Colborne in Berlin and Lena Klimkeit in Rome
Dateline: London (dpa) - 
Body
Passengers with low-cost airline Ryanair will no longer be able to take a 10-kilogram piece of hand luggage on 
board for free under a new policy introduced on Thursday.
Under the new rules, passengers who want to bring anything bigger than a "small personal bag" will be charged 
extra unless they are a priority boarding customer.
Priority boarding costs 6 euros (7 dollars). Customers who do not choose priority boarding will have to pay 10 euros 
for an extra piece of cabin baggage.
The new policy has provoked outrage on social media, with some customers claiming they will never fly with 
Ryanair again.
Italy's antitrust watchdog on Wednesday said in a statement that it was banning the new policy from taking effect in 
the country.
Bringing hand luggage on board a flight was an "essential component" of a flight, Antitrust Italia said in a statement, 
claiming that extra charges for hand luggage were misleading to customers.
The authority demanded the suspension all activities that involved charging customers extra to carry a large piece 
of hand luggage.
Ryanair has had a difficult year plagued by strike action across Europe. Last month, it reported a 7-per-cent fall in 
profits in the first half of its financial year, blaming "widespread damage" from the strikes, among other things.
Ryanair also came under heavy criticism last month for its lacklustre response to a passenger who launched a 
racist rant at the woman sitting next to him, after a video showing the incident was circulated on social media.
Ryanair introduces new hand luggage rules amid competition concerns
Editorial contactsEditing by: Friederike HeineTel: +49 30 2852 31472; <international@dpa.com;
Load-Date: November 2, 2018
End of Document
Ryanair introduces new hand luggage rules amid competition concerns
Ryanair introduces new hand luggage rules amid competition concerns
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
November 1, 2018 Thursday 1:51 PM GMT
Copyright 2018 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 290 words
Byline: Femke Colborne in Berlin and Lena Klimkeit in Rome
Dateline: London (dpa) - 
Body
Passengers with low-cost airline Ryanair will no longer be able to take a 10-kilogram piece of hand luggage on 
board for free under a new policy introduced on Thursday.
Under the new rules, passengers who want to bring anything bigger than a "small personal bag" will be charged 
extra unless they are a priority boarding customer.
Priority boarding costs 6 euros (7 dollars). Customers who do not choose priority boarding will have to pay 10 euros 
for an extra piece of cabin baggage.
The new policy has provoked outrage on social media, with some customers claiming they will never fly with 
Ryanair again.
Italy's antitrust watchdog on Wednesday said in a statement that it was banning the new policy from taking effect in 
the country.
Bringing hand luggage on board a flight was an "essential component" of a flight, Antitrust Italia said in a statement, 
claiming that extra charges for hand luggage were misleading to customers.
The authority demanded the suspension all activities that involved charging customers extra to carry a large piece 
of hand luggage.
Ryanair spokesman Robin Kiely said the airline would appeal the decision, and claimed the regulation is 
transparent and benefits customers.
Ryanair has had a difficult year plagued by strike action across Europe. Last month, it reported a 7-per-cent fall in 
profits in the first half of its financial year, blaming "widespread damage" from the strikes, among other things.
Ryanair introduces new hand luggage rules amid competition concerns
Ryanair also came under heavy criticism last month for its lacklustre response to a passenger who launched a 
racist rant at the woman sitting next to him, after a video showing the incident was circulated on social media.

Dutch court prohibits forced relocation of Dutch Ryanair pilots
Dutch court prohibits forced relocation of Dutch Ryanair pilots
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
November 1, 2018 Thursday 2:27 PM GMT
Copyright 2018 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 228 words
Byline: Annette Birschel in Amsterdam
Dateline: Amsterdam (dpa) - 
Body
Low-cost airline Ryanair cannot relocate 16 of its pilots based in the Netherlands to other countries, a Dutch court 
has ruled.
The court in the southern city of Den Bosch stopped the planned forced relocations on Thursday.
Ryanair said it will appeal the decision. The Irish airline had notified the pilots of the relocations on October 1 
because its site in the city of Eindhoven was being closed.
The pilots fought the decision in court, saying the forced relocations were a reaction to recent strikes.
The court agreed with their position on Thursday.
"It appears as though the decision was made as a penalty for earlier strikes," the court said in a statement.
Ryanair has had a difficult year plagued by strike action across Europe. Last month, it reported a 7-per-cent fall in 
profits in the first half of its financial year, blaming "widespread damage" from the strikes, among other things.
Dutch pilots joined the biggest strike in Ryanair's history in August, which led to cancellations across Europe.
Ryanair has announced the closing of its site at Eindhoven, but the court said the company hadn't sufficiently 
proven that the closure was necessary for business reasons.
According to the law in Ireland, where Ryanair is headquartered, such forced relocations would be allowed.
Editorial contactsEditing by: Shane Strowmatt, +49 30 2852 31472, <international@dpa.com;
Dutch court prohibits forced relocation of Dutch Ryanair pilots
Load-Date: November 2, 2018
End of Document

relocations on Thursday.  Ryanair said it will appeal the decision. The Irish airline had notified the pilots of the

Ryanair and CEO sued in New York court: report
Ryanair and CEO sued in New York court: report
AirFinance Journal
November 2018
Copyright 2018 Euromoney Institutional Investor PLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 499 words
Byline: Michael Allen
Body
Irish low-cost carrier Ryanair and its chief executive officer Michael O’Leary have been sued in New York by a 
shareholder, Reuters reports.
The City of Birmingham Firemen’s and Policemen’s Supplemental Pension System says the airline defrauded 
investors and inflated its share price by overstating its ability to manage labour relations and keep costs down.
The complaint was filed on 6 November in the US District Court in Manhattan by the Alabaman pension fund, 
seeking class-action status and damages for investors in Ryanair’s American depositary shares from 30 May 2017 
to 28 September 2018.
In a statement on 7 November, Ryanair said it will defend itself against the claims, which it called “false” and 
“doomed to fail”.
According to the complaint, Ryanair misled investors in regulatory filings and conference calls about its labour 
stability, including “industry leading” contracts with pilots and cabin crews, and its positive impact on operations.
The complaint alleges that the truth came out last December, when labour unrest forced Ryanair to recognise 
unions for the first time. The complaint also highlights this summer's costly strikes that stranded thousands of 
passengers in several countries.
“Unbeknownst to investors, the company’s historical profit growth was built on an undisclosed and unsustainable 
foundation of worker exploitation and employee turnover,” the complaint states. “The decline in the price of Ryanair 
ADSs was the direct result of the nature and extent of defendants’ fraud finally being revealed to investors and the 
market.”
Ryanair cited labour issues when it cut its full-year profit forecast on 1 October. Its share price closed that day more 
than one-third below its level in mid-March.
In the 7 November statement, Ryanair said it has experienced “very little” labour disruption from employees, and 
that most flight disruptions had resulted from air traffic control strikes and staff shortages, a problem common to 
European Union airlines.
Ryanair and CEO sued in New York court: report
O’Leary, Ryanair’s chief executive since 1994, said last month he hoped to reach labour agreements with all of the 
carrier’s major unions before Christmas.
On 30 June ADSs accounted for 43.7% of Ryanair’s issued ordinary shares, assuming all were converted into 
ordinary shares. Ryanair’s market value is roughly $16 billion, according to Refinitiv data cited by Reuters.
The City of Birmingham Firemen’s and Policemen’s Supplemental Pension System is represented by law firm 
Robbins Geller Rudman & Dowd, which specialises in securities fraud.
It is common for shareholders to sue companies in the United States after what they consider unexpected share 
price declines, Reuters says.
The case is City of Birmingham Firemen’s and Policemen’s Supplemental Pension System v Ryanair Holdings Plc, 
U.S. District Court, Southern District of New York, No. 18-10330.
Load-Date: February 12, 2019
End of Document
Court bans transfer of Dutch Ryanair pilots
Court bans transfer of Dutch Ryanair pilots
Associated Press Financial Wire
November 1, 2018 Thursday 2:48 PM GMT
Copyright 2018 Associated Press All Rights Reserved
Section: BUSINESS NEWS
Length: 179 words
Dateline: AMSTERDAM 
Body
AMSTERDAM (AP) - A court in the Netherlands banned Ryanair from transferring 16 pilots overseas following the 
closure of its Dutch base in Eindhoven, saying Thursday that the move appeared to be a reprisal by the budget 
carrier for strikes by Dutch employees.
The court in Den Bosch ruled that although the pilots' contracts are based on labor laws in Ryanair's home country 
of Ireland, the carrier cannot ignore Dutch regulations.
In a statement, the court said that choosing Irish labor law "does not mean that an employer can deprive employees 
of the protection offered by Dutch law."
Ryanair had argued that closing its operations at Eindhoven Airport was a commercial decision, but the court says it 
appears to be "a sanction for earlier strikes."
In a written reaction, Ryanair said if the pilots don't transfer they will be out of a job.
"All pilots and cabin crew have already been offered base transfers, which protects their seniority and earnings, but 
if any crew members wish to choose redundancies over base transfers then we will respect that choice," the 
company said.
Load-Date: November 2, 2018

dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
November 1, 2018 Thursday 9:58 AM GMT

Length: 193 words
Byline: Femke Colborne in Berlin

Body
Passengers with low-cost airline Ryanair will no longer be able to take a 10-kilogram piece of hand luggage on 
board for free under a new policy introduced on Thursday.
Under the new rules, passengers who want to bring anything bigger than a "small personal bag" will be charged 
extra unless they are a priority boarding customer.
Priority boarding costs 6 euros (7 dollars). Customers who do not choose priority boarding will have to pay 10 euros 
for an extra piece of cabin baggage.

Ryanair to appeal Italy 's suspension of hand luggage regulation
Ryanair to appeal Italy's suspension of hand luggage regulation
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
November 1, 2018 Thursday 12:58 PM GMT
Copyright 2018 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 89 words
Dateline: London (dpa) - 
Body
Low-cost airline Ryanair says it will appeal a decision by Italian competition authorities to suspend hand luggage 
regulations it introduced on November 1.
Ryanair spokesman Robin Kiely said the regulation, which means that passengers who want to bring anything 
bigger than a "small personal bag" on board will be charged extra, is transparent and benefits customers.
The news comes after Italy's antitrust watchdog demanded the suspension of all activities that involved charging 
customers extra to carry a large piece of hand luggage.

Following the issue, a 12-month placing programme in respect of up to a further 300 million ordinary shares and/or

Dutch court blocks Ryanair 's move to shut Eindhoven base
Dutch court blocks Ryanair's move to shut Eindhoven base
Business World (Digest)
November 01, 2018 Thursday
Copyright 2018 Media World Ltd. All Rights Reserved
Section: WORLD
Length: 190 words
Byline: Business World
Body
A Dutch court blocked Ryanair on Thursday in its attempt to shut its base in the Netherlands and move crew 
elsewhere, saying the Irish low-cost carrier had abused its powers as an employer.
Ryanair said last month it would shut its base in Eindhoven on Nov. 5, moving 16 pilots who operate flights from the 
southern Dutch airport to locations abroad in order to cut costs.
The district court in 's-Hertogenbosch said Ryanair had failed to explain why the move was necessary and said the 
decision seemed to be retaliation for the European-wide strikes Dutch pilots had joined in recent months.
Ryanair could not immediately be reached for comment.
Europe’s largest budget airline has struggled with labor relations since it bowed to pressure to recognize trade 
unions for the first time last December.
Two coordinated walkouts since August in Portugal, Germany, Spain, Belgium and the Netherlands hit passenger 
numbers, bookings and profits, the company said on Oct. 1.
The court said pilots operating from Eindhoven could not be moved abroad against their will, and forced Ryanair to 
adhere to Dutch labor laws. (Reuters)
Source: www.businessworld.ie
Load-Date: November 23, 2018
Dutch court blocks Ryanair 's move to shut Eindhoven base
End of Document

Laudamotion leases two A320s
Laudamotion leases two A320s
AirFinance Journal
November 2018
Copyright 2018 Euromoney Institutional Investor PLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 107 words
Byline: Jack Dutton
Body
Laudamotion, the Austrian airline that is part of the Ryanair Group, has agreed to lease two Airbus A320s from 
SMBC Aviation Capital.
The first aircraft was delivered to Laudamotion this week with the second aircraft due in January 2019.
This is the first aircraft delivered on lease to Laudamotion since the completion of Ryanair’s increased investment in 
the airline at the end of August. In all, Ryanair expects to double the existing Laudamotion fleet to 19. Ryanair 
initially purchased 24.9% of Laudamotion earlier this year and increased its shareholding to 75% during summer 
2018 following approval from the EU Competition Authority.

Ryanair repays subsidies after 737-800 seizure
Ryanair repays subsidies after 737-800 seizure
AirFinance Journal
November 2018
Copyright 2018 Euromoney Institutional Investor PLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 92 words
Byline: Alex Derber
Body
French bailiffs seized a Ryanair Boeing 737-800 aircraft last week in a bid to recover subsidies paid to the airline 
that the European Commission later deemed illegal.
According to the The Local, Ryanair has now repaid the &euro;525,000 ($590,000) that French authorities 
demanded for the return of its aircraft.
The sum concerned a subsidy scheme for Ryanair flights from Angoul&ecirc;me regional airport between 2008 and 
2009, the BBC reports.
The authorities impounded the aircraft on 8 November at Charente airport, forcing 149 passengers to disembark.
Load-Date: February 12, 2019
End of Document
Brussels Airport strike ends amid preliminary deal
Brussels Airport strike ends amid preliminary deal
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
October 31, 2018 Wednesday 4:32 PM GMT
Copyright 2018 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 242 words
Byline: Helen Fessenden in Brussels
Dateline: Brussels (dpa) - 
Body
Baggage handlers and the firm Aviapartner have reached a deal to end a strike that had disrupted operations at 
Brussels Airport, allowing normal operations to resume, the airport announced Wednesday.
"Aviapartner will gradually resume activities as of this afternoon, which will allow for a return to normal operations 
for the flights handled by Aviapartner," the airport said on its web site.
The airport added it "deplores the major impact this unannounced strike has had on passengers and airlines," 
noting that 960 flights were cancelled and almost 115,000 travellers were affected over the six-day strike.
The work stoppage came at a busy travel time in Belgium, when many schools have a term break.
Aviapartner workers had cited grievances over low wages, understaffing and a bonus that was promised but not 
fully paid, according to the news agency Belga.
Under the deal, Aviapartner will cut workloads, invest in more equipment amounting to 3.2 million euros (3.6 million 
dollars), approve new bonuses and monitor the implementation of these proposals, Belga reported, citing union 
officials.
The agreement would also see more workers hired and have more workers employed under contracts.
Aviapartner, which handles Brussels baggage for Ryanair, EasyJet, British Airways and TUI Fly, is contracted in 37 
airports in six European countries, according to its website.
Editorial contactsEditing by: Shane Strowmatt, +49 30 2852 31472, <international@dpa.com;
Brussels Airport strike ends amid preliminary deal
Load-Date: November 1, 2018
End of Document

flights were cancelled and almost 115,000 travellers were affected over the six-day strike.  The work stoppage

euros (3.6 million dollars), approve new bonuses and monitor the implementation of these proposals, Belga

6-day strike by baggage handlers at Brussels airport ends
6-day strike by baggage handlers at Brussels airport ends
Associated Press Financial Wire
October 31, 2018 Wednesday 2:23 PM GMT
Copyright 2018 Associated Press All Rights Reserved
Section: BUSINESS NEWS
Length: 90 words
Dateline: BRUSSELS 
Body
BRUSSELS (AP) - Unions and management have found agreement to end a six-day strike by baggage handlers 
that has disrupted flights to and from Belgium's main airport for part of the autumn holiday season.
Workers at the Aviapartner luggage handling company went back to work on Wednesday after they won guarantees 
for better working conditions. The company serves major companies like Ryanair, TUI, easyJet and British Airways.
Overall, 960 flights were cancelled affecting 115,000 passengers. Some of the traffic was diverted to nearby 
airports.

Gate huggers: should airports look to deploy more retail at boarding areas?
Gate huggers: should airports look to deploy more retail at boarding areas?
MarketLine NewsWire (Formerly Datamonitor)
October 31, 2018 Wednesday 6:30 PM GMT
Copyright 2018 MarketLine All Rights Reserved
Section: AUTOMOTIVE, TRANSPORT AND LOGISTICS
Length: 1347 words
Highlight: Many airports worldwide are taking big steps to appease passengers' inner shopper. Aviation hubs such 
as London Heathrow, Singapore Changi and Hong Kong International now offer a staggering array of retail, food 
and beverage options.
Body
A report published last year by Airports Council International revealed that non-aeronautical cash sources continued 
to constitute 40% of global airport revenues and had reached an industry value of $60.4bn.However, some airports 
are beginning to recognise a frustrating passenger demographic the media likes to call ‘gate huggers’: lounge-shy 
travellers who tend to walk straight to their boarding gate rather than explore the retail playground of the departure 
lounge.On the face of it, passengers that refuse to be swayed by duty-free mega-zones present a potential loss for 
airports and retailers. But could they provide an incentive for new retail opportunities at boarding gates?The causes 
of gate huggingThe ‘gate hugging’ trend can be put down to a number of different factors, says Chris van 
R&yuml;sw&yuml;ck, associate director of Pragma Consulting and a former commercial performance manager at 
London Gatwick Airport. At the top of his list are nervous fliers, who may be concerned about missing their flight 
and therefore tend to hover near gates.The rise of low-cost-carriers (LCCs), such as Ryanair, could also amplify 
these concerns. As LCCs often lock aircraft hold space behind a paywall, many passengers only carry hand 
baggage and know that arriving late could result in their bags being stowed in the hold.Other passengers may 
simply lack an interest in airport retail or want to get away from the hustle and bustle of departure lounges. 
This, Van R&yuml;sw&yuml;ck says, is something many modern-day airport departure lounges don’t always 
accommodate for.“Many airports provide very limited passenger seating and passengers who want to sit down 
know there are seats at the gate rooms,” he says.David Lenot, airport practice leader at video surveillance 
specialist Genetec, says delays at security can cripple a passenger’s desire to shop. However, he also says that 
gate hugging might be a side effect of cultural differences.“You may have people come from specific countries 
where people would be more prone not to use retail or simply have a habit of sticking closer to the gate earlier,” he 
says.A US-led phenomenonIndeed, when it comes to airports, Van R&yuml;sw&yuml;ck says that there is a 
massive cultural difference between the US and the rest of the world. Gate hugging could be more of a US 
phenomenon due to the way those airports are structured.Most airports worldwide feature a separate holding 
Gate huggers: should airports look to deploy more retail at boarding areas?
lounge where passengers can shop before they are called to the gate, where retail offers are usually more limited. 
However in the US, many airports – aside from the few that have been privatised – consist of a ‘processing head-
house’ owned by a port authority, followed by concourses which are airline-owned.Because airlines manage these 
post-security zones, passengers know roughly where their gate will be from the outset and are therefore more 
inclined to move into those areas sooner. Van R&yuml;sw&yuml;ck says that this could be a reason why boarding 
gates at US airports feature a stronger retail offering.“Because [the processing head house] is a port authority-run 
service, they are not looking to overly commercialise it,” he explains. “They get some income from it, but it’s not a 
main focus, just as the British Airport Authority airports back in the early 80s and 70s were government-owned and 
not pleasant places to be.”Bringing dining options to the gateAirports in the US have already begun finding ways to 
accommodate ‘gate huggers’, while combining it with another trend not exclusive to airports – the modern-day 
individual’s overwhelming desire to look at screens.One concept being explored is a ‘mobile retail cart’, which could 
be parked at certain gates and offer products tailored to passengers based on their destination. Meanwhile, 
customers at JFK International, Washington National and Newark Liberty are able to order food from a suite of 
iPads set up near boarding gates.Start-ups have taken the latter idea and are running with it. The Airport Sherpa 
app allows passengers at Baltimore Washington International to order food or duty-free items from their phones. 
Goods can be picked up from shops or delivered anywhere in the airport – including at the gate. The app even 
tracks passengers’ flight schedule, ensuring that deliveries can go ahead even in the event of a gate change.“Gate 
hugging is a very natural thing to do – I do it,” says Airport Sherpa co-founder Mayank Gandhi. “I don’t want to miss 
my flight or miss the opportunity to store my carry-on in the overhead bin before it runs out of space. But that 
shouldn’t mean I have to settle for what’s next to my gate.”Airport Sherpa’s CEO Patrick DellaValle says the app 
allows passengers to access duty-free and food offerings they might not otherwise have access to – if it’s in a 
different terminal, for example – thus improving the scope of an airport’s retail investment.The app is set to launch 
at a number of US airports in the future, but DellaValle also thinks the idea could have appeal at airports 
abroad.“When we talk with airport partners in Europe they still see the same value proposition,” he says. “Certainly 
there are going to be aspects which are a bit different, but when they run their analysis of what their customers want 
from an experience standpoint – alongside the key drivers that they see as being able to increase overall revenue – 
our service offering fits exactly what they are looking for.”Finding the ‘critical mass’PQ: Retailers need to consider 
whether they will have the ‘critical mass’ required to make their operational costs worthwhileUS airports may be 
taking steps to monetise gate rooms, but should airports elsewhere take the plunge?Lenot says the first step should 
be finding out whether passengers are actually dwelling for too long at the gate. Nowadays, airports can use a 
variety of technologies to understand the movement and behaviour of passengers through terminals, giving them 
key performance indicators that they can then apply to their retail strategies. Genetec’s Airport Sense solution, for 
example, uses cameras and sensors to provide actionable intelligence about passenger flow through terminals.“If 
you could use CCTV cameras or any other measuring technology, you would be able to assess the dwell time of 
people in the seating area next to the gate, so that’s a good indicator,” says Lenot.Van R&yuml;sw&yuml;ck says 
airports would have to be careful when they consider offering a larger retail offer at gate rooms, as it could 
‘cannibalise’ the revenues from their existing retail mega-hubs.Whether retailers are setting up shop on the high 
street or at airports, they need to consider whether they will have the ‘critical mass’ required to make their 
operational costs worthwhile. Ultimately, airports that operate a call-to-gate strategy might not be able to guarantee 
this – particularly if the overwhelming majority of consumers pick up items in the departure lounge.“If I’m a 
concessionaire looking to buy space and the airport says, ‘I’ve got this great location, but only 3% of our 
passengers per annum go to that particular gate room’, my critical mass for being able to service that location is 
suddenly tremendously diminished,” Van R&yuml;sw&yuml;ck says.“I would give the gate huggers a reason not to 
hug the gate. If people want a quiet area, then provide a quiet area. If people are nervous, communicate your way-
finding more effectively and make people comfortable that they aren’t going to miss their flights so they are happy to 
stay in that commercial environment.“That to me is not only an easier solution, but also one that I think would 
deliver better returns.”
Load-Date: November 7, 2018
End of Document
Workers, management near deal to end Brussels Airport strike
Workers, management near deal to end Brussels Airport strike
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
October 31, 2018 Wednesday 9:51 AM GMT
Copyright 2018 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 167 words
Byline: Helen Fessenden in Brussels
Dateline: Brussels (dpa) - 
Body
Baggage handlers and management are close to reaching an agreement that would end a strike that has disrupted 
operations at Brussels Airport, the news service Belga reported Wednesday.
The strike by employees of the services company Aviapartner, which started last Thursday, cited grievances over 
low wages, understaffing and a bonus that was promised but not fully paid.
According to union officials, strikers will review the deal at 11 am (1000 GMT), at which point some people would 
return to work, Belga reported. The deal includes bonuses and an increase in the number of contract positions.
The strike resulted in scores of flight cancellations each day and came at a busy travel time in Belgium, when many 
schools have a term break.
Aviapartner, which handles Brussels baggage for Ryanair, EasyJet, British Airways and TUI Fly, is contracted in 37 
airports in six European countries, according to its website.
Editorial contactsEditing by: Friederike HeineTel: +49 30 2852 31472; <international@dpa.com;

strike by employees of the services company Aviapartner, which started last Thursday, cited grievances over low

airports in six European countries, according to its website.   Copyright dpa

Baggage handlers and management have reached a preliminary agreement to end a strike that has disrupted 
operations at Brussels Airport, the news service Belga reported Wednesday.
The six-day old strike by employees of the services company Aviapartner had cited grievances over low wages, 
understaffing and a bonus that was promised but not fully paid.
Under the deal, Aviapartner will cut workloads, invest in more equipment amounting to 3.2 million euros (3.6 million 
dollars), approve new bonuses and monitor the implementation of these proposals, Belga reported, citing union 
officials.
The agreement would also see more workers hired and have more workers employed under contracts.
The strike resulted in scores of flight cancellations each day and came at a busy travel time in Belgium, when many 
schools have a term break.

Ryanair shareholder calls for chairman's ouster
Ryanair shareholder calls for chairman's ouster
Business World (Digest)
October 30, 2018 Tuesday
Copyright 2018 Media World Ltd. All Rights Reserved
Section: WORLD
Length: 336 words
Byline: Business World
Body
Britain's Local Authority Pension Fund Forum (LAPFF), which represents funds that own a combined 
1% of Ryanair, on Sunday said it planned to file resolutions at the company's next annual general meeting to 
replace Chairman David Bonderman.
The group, which opposed Bonderman's re-election at last month's AGM, said it would lobby fellow shareholders to 
join it to secure the 3% of shares required to file a shareholder resolution at the next meeting, due in September 
2019.
The group also plans to file a resolution demanding that succession plans for Chief Executive Michael O'Leary be 
set out.
"On the day of Ryanair's first-half results (Oct. 22) Mr O'Leary said Mr Bonderman intends to remain in place for 
one or two more years and that the company would set out succession plans for Mr O'Leary in the next two or three 
years," the LAPFF said in a statement.
"Shareholders have made it clear they expect action quicker than this."
The group said it believed recent staffing and industrial relations issues at Ryanair might have been handled better 
with a more independent board.
It said its concerns had been heightened by a profit warning on Oct. 1. when Ryanair cut its forecast for full-year 
profit by 12% citing damage to bookings from strikes.
Ryanair shareholder calls for chairman's ouster
The LAPFF was one of several shareholders to voice concerns at Ryanair's AGM in September, when Bonderman, 
was re-elected with 70.5% of votes, a significant fall from the 89% he received the previous year.
"Ryanair shareholders recently passed all AGM resolutions by a large majority, including the nomination of directors 
and chairman," a Ryanair spokesman said when asked to comment on the LAPFF's plan.
"They appreciate how fortunate we are to have an outstanding Chairman like David Bonderman guide the board 
and the airline."
Bonderman, the founder of private equity firm TPG Capital who has chaired Ryanair since 1996, resigned from the 
board of Uber in 2017 after an ill-judged joke that more women on the board means "more talking". (Reuters)
Source: www.businessworld.ie
Load-Date: November 20, 2018
End of Document
Head-To-Head Analysis: Ryanair ( RYAAY ) vs. Mesa Air Group ( MESA )
Head-To-Head Analysis: Ryanair (RYAAY) vs. Mesa Air Group (MESA)
American Banking and Market News
October 30, 2018 Tuesday
Copyright 2018 American Banking and Market News All Rights Reserved
Length: 537 words
Body
Ryanair (NASDAQ:RYAAY ) and Mesa Air Group (           NASDAQ:MESA ) are both transportation companies, but 
which is the superior investment? We will compare the two companies based on the strength of their analyst 
recommendations, risk, earnings, profitability, institutional ownership, valuation and dividends.  
Insider & Institutional Ownership
43.9% of Ryanair shares are held by institutional investors. Comparatively, 0.0% of Mesa Air Group shares are held 
by institutional investors. Strong institutional ownership is an indication that endowments, large money managers 
and hedge funds believe a company is poised for long-term growth.

Summary
Ryanair beats Mesa Air Group on 7 of the 11 factors compared between the two stocks. 
Ryanair Company Profile
Ryanair logo Ryanair Holdings plc, together with its subsidiaries, provides scheduled-passenger airline services in 
Ireland, the United Kingdom, and Other European countries. The company is also involved in the provision of 
various ancillary services, such as non-flight scheduled services and Internet-related services; in-flight sale of 
beverages, food, and merchandise; and marketing accommodation services, holidays, car hire, and travel 
insurance through its Website. In addition, it sells bus and rail tickets onboard its aircraft and through its Website, as 
well as gift vouchers through its Website; and markets car parking, attractions, and activities through its Website. As 
of June 30, 2018, the company operated a fleet of 440 Boeing 737 aircraft; and offered approximately 2,000 
scheduled short-haul flights per day serving approximately 200 airports in Europe. Ryanair Holdings plc was 
founded in 1985 and is headquartered in Swords, Ireland. 
Mesa Air Group Company Profile
Mesa Air Group logo Mesa Air Group, Inc. operates as the holding company for Mesa Airlines, Inc., which provides 
regional air services under capacity purchase agreements with the American Airlines and the United Airlines. As of 
March 31, 2018, it operated 145 aircraft with approximately 610 daily departures to 110 cities in the United States, 
Canada, Mexico, the Bahamas, and Cuba. Mesa Air Group, Inc. was founded in 1982 and is headquartered in 
Phoenix, Arizona.

Companies Rule Out Interest in Alitalia, in Blow to Rescue Plan
Companies Rule Out Interest in Alitalia, in Blow to Rescue Plan
Newstex Blogs
Voice of America
October 30, 2018 Tuesday 9:06 PM EST
Copyright 2018 Newstex LLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 513 words
Body
Oct 30, 2018( Voice of America: http://www.voanews.com Delivered by Newstex)  Major companies on Tuesday 
ruled out involvement in a new rescue of Alitalia, complicating a plan led by Rome in which state-controlled railway 
Ferrovie dello Stato (FS) will bid for the airline this week and bring in partners. Alitalia was put under special 
administration last year, leaving the government once again looking to find a buyer to save the carrier. 
It will be the airline's third rescue in a decade. FS is due to present an offer for the whole of Alitalia on Wednesday 
subject to a series of conditions. FS's offer would only be a "transitional phase," a source close to the deal told 
Reuters. The source added the deal would be completed in two separate steps, with FS picking up Alitalia on set 
conditions and then, at a later stage, being joined by an Italian partner and a international one, from the airline 
sector. The source added there was very little visibility on next steps, and it was not clear which partners would join 
FS. "The situation is very messy," the source said. Earlier this month Deputy Prime Minister Luigi Di Maio 
suggested that state-controlled companies like oil major Eni , postal operator Poste and defense group Leonardo 
could all play a role in the relaunch. Di Maio, also industry minister, said that there were many private investors also 
interested in Alitalia. But on Tuesday Eni said that any suggestion that it might pick up a stake in the carrier was 
"groundless" and that it would not play a role in the rescue, a spokesperson said. Leonardo too will not join any 
relaunch of Alitalia, which has already accumulated a loss of over 300 million euros ($340.86 million), a separate 
source close to the matter told Reuters. "It would be crazy for Leonardo to enter this madness," the source said. 
Shares in the group were down almost 1.5 percent at 1600 GMT after Italian dailies had reported that the company 
would be involved in an effort spearheaded by FS. Last month Poste Chief Executive Matteo del Fante said the 
group was "not at all interested" in joining an overhaul effort for the airline. Cash drain Alitalia has cost Italian tax 
payers almost 10 billion euros over the last 20 years, more than the market capitalization of Air France-KLM, 
Turkish Airlines, Norwegian Air, Finnair and SAS added together, according to Andrea Giuricin, CEO of transport 
advisory firm TRA Consulting. Last year Alitalia accounted for only 8.5 percent of the international traffic to and from 
Italy, Giuricin added, just under a third of Ryanair's share. The sale process was delayed due to the change of 
Italian government earlier this year, but the ruling coalition, that comprises the anti-establishment 5-Star Movement 
and the far-right League, pledged it would close a deal by Wednesday. Germany's Lufthansa said earlier on 
Tuesday that it had no interest in participating in a government-led restructuring effort. Alitalia must pay back the 
Italian state almost 1 billion euros in a bridge loan and related interest by mid-December. ($1 = 0.8801 euros) 
Load-Date: October 31, 2018
Companies Rule Out Interest in Alitalia, in Blow to Rescue Plan
End of Document

Monday Papers: Financial conditions tighten as markets tumble
Citywire
October 29, 2018 Monday 3:32 AM GMT
Copyright 2018 Citywire Financial Publishers All Rights Reserved
Length: 525 words
Byline: Himanshu Singh
Highlight: And Tesla backer Baillie Gifford is ready to put more money behind Elon Musk.
Body

•

according to closely watched Goldman Sachs’ financial conditions index.
•
The Times: Baillie Gifford, the Scottish fund manager that owns nearly 8% of Tesla, has said that it would 
be willing to plough more cash into the electric car maker, despite the controversy surrounding its founder.
•

was used by sports stars, celebrities and financiers to illegally avoid paying £700 million in tax.
•

for using speculation about a merger with Commerzbank as an excuse for its poor performance.
•
Financial Times: The Thai billionaire and owner of Leicester City Football Club, Vichai Srivaddhanaprabha, 
died in a helicopter crash outside the Premier League club’s home ground.
•
Financial Times: Chinese banks have started using Ping An micro-expression technology in an effort to 
spot the early signs of fraud in customers’ facial movements.
Business and economics
•
The Times: EY partners are in for a pay rise after the firm posted record revenues; EY’s 680 British 
partners received an average £693,000 each in the year to June 30, £15,000 more than last year.
•
The Times: Landsec, which owns Trinity Leeds and Gunwharf Quays in Portsmouth, is drawing up plans to 
build flats above and around its shopping centres in an attempt to counteract the pressure on retail 
property valuations.
•
The Times: The stationery chain Paperchase has recorded loss of £6.3 million, compared with a profit of 
£613,000 the year before and its earnings have halved after fewer people visited its British shops.
•
The Guardian: Ryanair investors are mounting pressure on the airline to bring in fresh leadership as they 
call for its chairman, David Bonderman, to stand down after more than 20 years.
•
Daily Mail: Patisserie Valerie is facing calls for a boardroom clear-out, with potential buyers also circling the 
embattled café chain.
Monday Papers: Financial conditions tighten as markets tumble
•
The Times: Liam Fox’s trade department has spent more than £1 million on overseas trips and missions in 
an effort to maintain economic ties with key markets and pave the way for post-Brexit trade deals.
Share tips, comment and bids
•
The Daily Telegraph (Questor share tips): Direct Line’s shares may not be motoring but the 6% yield 
makes them a hold.
•
The Guardian: Epic Games, the company behind the Fortnite video game, has been valued at almost $15 
billion after receiving a $1.25 billion cash injection led by the private equity firm KKR.
•
The Daily Telegraph: Computing giant IBM has become the largest hybrid cloud provider with a $34 billion 
deal to buy software company Red Hat.
•
Financial Times: Network Rail, which owns and manages the UK’s infrastructure, has asked the European 
Commission to intervene in the proposed Siemens/Alstom merger.
•

defence deals.
•

Baggage handlers' strike grounds flights at Brussels Airport
Baggage handlers' strike grounds flights at Brussels Airport
Associated Press Financial Wire
October 29, 2018 Monday 1:08 PM GMT
Copyright 2018 Associated Press All Rights Reserved
Section: BUSINESS NEWS
Length: 113 words
Dateline: BRUSSELS 
Body
BRUSSELS (AP) - A strike by baggage handlers is disrupting flights to and from Belgium's main airport for a fifth 
day.
Workers at the Aviapartner luggage handling company are striking to back their demands for better working 
conditions. The company serves major companies like Ryanair, TUI, EasyJet and British Airways.
Dozens of flights to and from Brussels Airport were canceled Monday as union representatives and management 
continue negotiations.
The work stoppage left passengers wondering how they would reach their destinations.
Jason Glassy, who was supposed to be flying to Barcelona, says, "I am just waiting in the line to see what the 
alternative is, I am not too sure."
Load-Date: October 30, 2018
End of Document
European ADRs Move Higher in Monday Trading
European ADRs Move Higher in Monday Trading
MT Newswires Live Briefs
October 29, 2018 Monday 10:37 AM EST
Copyright 2018 MT Newswires All Rights Reserved
Length: 183 words
Body
 American depositary receipts of European stocks were trading 1.43% higher at 125.74 on the Bank of New York 
Mellon Europe ADR Index on Monday.
In continental Europe, the gainers were led by biopharmaceutical company Grifols (GRFS), which surged 8.7%. It 
was followed by pharmaceutical company Oasmia Pharmaceutical (OASM), and semiconductor company 
STMicroelectronics (STM) which rose 7% and 6.2%.
The only decliners in continental Europe were biotech company Forward Pharma (FWP), which tumbled 11.6%, 
and semiconductor company Sequans Communications (SQNS), which lost 2.2%.
In the UK and Ireland, the gainers were led by banks HSBC (HSBC), Barclays Bank (BCS), and Royal Bank of 
Scotland (RBS), which rose 5.4%, 4.4%, and 4% respectively. They were followed by telecommunications operator 
BT Group (BT), which climbed 3.2%.
The decliners in the UK and Ireland were led by Verona Pharma (VRNA), which fell 2.9%. It was followed by airline 
operator Ryanair (RYAAY), and biopharmaceutical company Adaptimmune Therapeutics (ADAP), which were off 
0.5% each.
Price: 7.30, Change: +0.30, Percent Change: +4.29
Load-Date: October 30, 2018
End of Document
Flights cancelled at Brussels Airport amid strike by baggage-handlers
Flights cancelled at Brussels Airport amid strike by baggage-handlers
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
October 29, 2018 Monday 4:49 PM GMT
Copyright 2018 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 184 words
Byline: Helen Fessenden in Brussels
Dateline: Brussels (dpa) - 
Body
Brussels Airport continues to struggle with a strike by baggage handlers, cancelling a further 100 flights on Monday, 
according to the news agency Belga.
The strike by employees of the services company Aviapartner started on Thursday evening. After a pause, 
Aviapartner's management and the unions resumed talks Monday morning. But the two sides remain far apart.
The strike comes at a busy travel time. Many schools across Belgium have a term break this week to coincide with 
the All Saints' holiday on Thursday.
About 350,000 people were expected to travel via Brussels Airport during this period, according to Belga.
Among the list of strikers' grievances are low wages, understaffing and a bonus that was promised but not fully 
paid. A trade union statement cited "a total absence of social consultation" within the company, Belga reported.
Aviapartner, which handles Brussels baggage for Ryanair, EasyJet, British Airways and TUI Fly, is contracted in 37 
airports in six European countries, according to its website.
Editorial contactsEditing by: Robin PowellTel: +49 30 2852-31472; <international@dpa.com;
Load-Date: October 30, 2018
End of Document

of strikers' grievances are low wages, understaffing and a bonus that was promised but not fully paid. A trade union

Pobeda deal for 20 737 Max includes high-density option E Russian budget airline Pobeda is committing to 
acquiring 20 Boeing 737 Max 8s, with an option to conve....
Pobeda deal for 20 737 Max includes high-density option;  E Russian budget 
airline Pobeda is committing to acquiring 20 Boeing 737 Max 8s, with an 
option to convert some to the high-density ‘Max 200’ variant.
Flight International
October 29, 2018
Copyright 2018 Reed Business Information Ltd. All Rights Reserved
Section: FLIGHTGLOBAL.COM
Length: 192 words
Body
Russian budget airline Pobeda is committing to acquiring 20 Boeing 737 Max 8s, with an option to convert some to 
the high-density ‘Max 200’ variant.
It is to take 15 of the aircraft from lessor SMBC Aviation Capital and another five from GECAS, it states in a formal 
procurement notice.
Pobeda’s aircraft from SMBC will come with a conversion option to switch seven of them to the ‘Max 200’ 
configuration.
This version has 197 seats, compared with the normal 189, and has already been ordered by budget carriers 
Ryanair and VietJet.
The five GECAS aircraft will all be regular Max 8s, the airline’s notice indicates.
Pobeda puts the value of the SMBC batch at $1.235 billion and that of the GECAS aircraft at $375 million.
The aircraft are all exclusively powered by CFM International Leap-1B engines.
Moscow Vnukovo-based Pobeda is already a Boeing 737-800 operator but had recently signalled that it was looking 
at the re-engined Max variant during a recruitment drive for pilots.
Pobeda estimates that the delivery of the SMBC aircraft will begin in November 2019 and run to November 2021, 
while that of the GECAS jets will take place in the first half of 2020.
Load-Date: October 29, 2018
Pobeda deal for 20 737 Max includes high-density option E Russian budget airline Pobeda is committing to 
acquiring 20 Boeing 737 Max 8s, with an option to conve....
End of Document
Investor calls for change at Ryanair
Investor calls for change at Ryanair
City A.M.
October 29, 2018 Monday
Edition 1, National Edition
Copyright 2018 City A.M. All Rights Reserved
Section: NEWS; Pg. 5
Length: 189 words
Byline: JAMES BOOTH
Body
RYANAIR shareholder the Local Authority Pension Fund Forum (LAPFF) yesterday called for the replacement of 
the budget airline's chairman David Bonderman and for a succession plan for its boss Michael O'Leary.
LAPFF said it plans to file resolutions at Ryanair's annual meeting (AGM) next year to replace Bonderman who has 
been in the post for 22 years. The UK's corporate governance code says that a chair should serve for no longer 
than nine years.
It also called for the company to layout a succession plan for longstanding chief executive Michael O'Leary in the 
next two to three years.
LAPFF said that Bonderman "presides over a board that is not sufficiently independent" and said he has been 
"unsuccessful in his oversight of employment issues at the company and ensuring customers receive adequate 
service during flight cancellations in summer 2018".
A Ryanair spokesperson said: "Ryanair shareholders recently passed all AGM resolutions by a large majority, 
including the nomination of directors and chairman. They appreciate how fortunate we are to have an outstanding 
chairman like David Bonderman guide the board and the airline."
Graphic

Flying into trouble: a Ryanair shareholder is calling for a new chairman at the airline

Massachusetts Financial Services Co. MA Purchases 173,885 Shares of Ryanair Holdings plc ( RYAAY )
Massachusetts Financial Services Co. MA Purchases 173,885 Shares of 
Ryanair Holdings plc (RYAAY)
American Banking and Market News
October 28, 2018 Sunday
Copyright 2018 American Banking and Market News All Rights Reserved
Length: 623 words
Body
Ryanair logo Massachusetts Financial Services Co. MA increased its stake in  Ryanair Holdings plc 
(NASDAQ:RYAAY) by 6.8% during the third quarter, according to its most recent Form 13F filing with the SEC. The 
firm owned 2,713,082 shares of the transportation company's stock after purchasing an additional 173,885 shares 
during the period. Massachusetts Financial Services Co. MA owned approximately 1.16% of Ryanair worth 
$260,564,000 as of its most recent filing with the SEC.  
Other hedge funds and other institutional investors also recently modified their holdings of the company. Castleark 
Management LLC increased its position in shares of  Ryanair by 305.2% in the second quarter. Castleark 
Management LLC now owns 10,210 shares of the transportation company's stock worth $1,166,000 after 
purchasing an additional 7,690 shares during the period.  Mitsubishi UFJ Kokusai Asset Management Co. Ltd. 
increased its position in shares of  Ryanair by 1,804.1% in the second quarter. Mitsubishi UFJ Kokusai Asset 
Management Co. Ltd. now owns 12,643 shares of the transportation company's stock worth $1,444,000 after 
purchasing an additional 11,979 shares during the period.  Lucia Wealth Services LLC bought a new position in 
shares of  Ryanair in the second quarter worth $408,000.  Great West Life Assurance Co. Can increased its 
position in shares of  Ryanair by 30.5% in the second quarter. Great West Life Assurance Co. Can now owns 
166,461 shares of the transportation company's stock worth $19,008,000 after purchasing an additional 38,913 
shares during the period.  Finally, Capital Fund Management S.A. increased its position in shares of  Ryanair by 
28.8% in the second quarter. Capital Fund Management S.A. now owns 24,847 shares of the transportation 
company's stock worth $2,838,000 after purchasing an additional 5,557 shares during the period. Institutional 
investors own  43.93% of the company's stock.  
RYAAY has been the topic of several research analyst reports. BidaskClub lowered Ryanair from a "sell" rating to a 
"strong sell" rating in a research note on Thursday, September 13th. Royal Bank of Canada  reaffirmed a "buy" 
rating on shares of Ryanair in a research note on Thursday, August 16th. UBS Group  reaffirmed a "buy" rating on 
shares of Ryanair in a research note on Wednesday, August 15th. ValuEngine  raised Ryanair from a "sell" rating to 
a "hold" rating in a research note on Monday, September 17th. Finally, Raymond James lowered Ryanair from an 
"outperform" rating to a "market perform" rating in a research note on Thursday, August 9th. Two research analysts 
have rated the stock with a sell rating, seven have assigned  a hold rating and three have issued  a buy rating to the 
company. The company  has a consensus rating of "Hold" and an average price target of $138.00. 
Massachusetts Financial Services Co. MA Purchases 173,885 Shares of Ryanair Holdings plc ( RYAAY )
Shares of RYAAY stock  opened at $82.17 on Friday. Ryanair Holdings plc has a 12 month low of $77.96 and a 12 
month high of $127.61. The stock has a market cap of $19.01 billion, a PE ratio of 11.66 and a beta of 0.55. The 
company has a current ratio of 1.25, a quick ratio of 1.12 and a debt-to-equity ratio of 0.62.  
Ryanair Profile
Ryanair Holdings plc, together with its subsidiaries, provides scheduled-passenger airline services in Ireland, the 
United Kingdom, and Other European countries. The company is also involved in the provision of various ancillary 
services, such as non-flight scheduled services and Internet-related services; in-flight sale of beverages, food, and 
merchandise; and marketing accommodation services, holidays, car hire, and travel insurance through its Website.

Institutional Ownership by Quarter for Ryanair (NASDAQ:RYAAY)

Ryanair rejects claim it did not apologise to racial abuse victim News round-up
Ryanair rejects claim it did not apologise to racial abuse victim; News round-
up
Financial Times (London, England)
October 27, 2018 Saturday
Edition 1, National Edition
Copyright 2018 The Financial Times Limited All Rights Reserved
Section: NEWS; Pg. 18
Length: 328 words
Byline: JOSH SPERO
Body
Low-cost carrier Ryanair has issued a statement to clarify its response to an incident in which a woman was racially 
abused on one of its flights, and accused the daughter of the victim of making an "untrue" claim about whether the 
airline made an apology.
Ryanair also implied its cabin crew had not understood the seriousness of the incident as passengers boarded a 
flight from Barcelona to Stansted on Friday October 19.
In a statement, Ryanair said it "immediately wrote ... to the female passenger at 11am on Sunday [October 21], 
apologising for what happened on board the aircraft ... We also invited the passenger to contact the airline if they 
wished to discuss the matter. The claim made in the media in recent days, that Ryanair did not contact or apologise 
to the female passenger, is untrue."
Carol Gayle, daughter of victim Delsie Gayle, said after the incident: "Nobody has apologised. We've had nothing. 
We just want an apology from Ryanair."
However, yesterday Ryanair made public copies of a letter and an email that it said had been sent last Sunday to 
Ms Gayle: "On behalf of Ryanair, may I sincerely apologise for what happened on board our aircraft," the letter said.
Ryanair rejects claim it did not apologise to racial abuse victim News round-up
Ryanair said it only became aware of a video of the incident - in which a man identified as David Mesher racially 
abused Mrs Gayle - late on Saturday, October 20. The airline said it reported the incident to police the next 
morning.
Mr Mesher said yesterday he was "not a racist" and apologised, saying he had just had a "fit of temper".
The airline said that Spanish cabin crew were aware of an argument between the two passengers during the 
boarding process, "but were not aware of, as they were not present, racist comments that were made".
Robin Kiely, head of communications at Ryanair, said the airline had "treated [the incident] with the urgency and 
seriousness it warranted".
"We trust that this statement will address the inaccurate media coverage of this incident over recent days."
Load-Date: October 27, 2018
End of Document
Travel & Leisure Ryanair (RYA) HOLD
Travel & Leisure Ryanair (RYA) HOLD
Financial Times (London, England)
October 27, 2018 Saturday
Edition 1, Asian Edition
Copyright 2018 The Financial Times Limited All Rights Reserved
Section: MONEY;BUSINESS; Pg. 11
Length: 281 words
Body
If the oil price rises, or if average fares fall further, morecapacity cuts look likely for thebudgetcarrier It was a 
turbulent firsthalf for Ryanair following ongoing pilot disputes and air traffic controller strikes in continental Europe. 
In early October, management warned pre-tax profits would land between (EURO)1.1bn (£97m) and (EURO)1.2bn-
a12 per cent downgrade on expectations .
investor.s were pleasantly surprised, then, that this figure actually came to (EURO)1.3bn, with the shares up about 
5 per cent on results day. Passenger numbers increased by 6 per cent to 76.6m, with load factor maintained at 96 
per cent, although the average fare fell 3 per cent to under (EURO)46.
Improvements in ancillary revenue, up nearly a third during the period to (EURO)1.3bn, were offset bcmad by 
higher fuel, staff and compensation costs. Although more than 100 new routes were added to the summer 2018 
season, weaker fares and higher oil prices forced the airline to trim winter capacity by 1 per cent. Even so, 
management still expects traffic numbers to increase to around 141m by the end of the financial year, boosted by 
Ryanair's 75 per cent stake in Austrian airline Laudamotion.
Analysts at UBS expect earnings per share of 970 cents during the year to March 2019, compared with 1,200 cents 
in full-year 2018.
While higher fuel prices added to first-half costs, 90 per cent of Ryanair's fuel needs for the next 12 months." are 
hedged at $68 per barrel-well below the $85 spot price. Still, we are wary of recent volatility to turn bullish just yet, 
especially when the shares look expensive compared with their historical two-year trading average and the wider 
sector. Julia Faurschou

Body
If the oil price rises, or if average fares fall further, morecapacity cuts look likely for thebudgetcarrier It was a 
turbulent firsthalf for Ryanair following ongoing pilot disputes and air traffic controller strikes in continental Europe. 
In early October, management warned pre-tax profits would land between (EURO)1.1bn (£97m) and (EURO)1.2bn-
a12 per cent downgrade on expectations .
investor.s were pleasantly surprised, then, that this figure actually came to (EURO)1.3bn, with the shares up about 
5 per cent on results day. Passenger numbers increased by 6 per cent to 76.6m, with load factor maintained at 96 
per cent, although the average fare fell 3 per cent to under (EURO)46.
Improvements in ancillary revenue, up nearly a third during the period to (EURO)1.3bn, were offset bcmad by 
higher fuel, staff and compensation costs. Although more than 100 new routes were added to the summer 2018 
season, weaker fares and higher oil prices forced the airline to trim winter capacity by 1 per cent. Even so, 
management still expects traffic numbers to increase to around 141m by the end of the financial year, boosted by 
Ryanair's 75 per cent stake in Austrian airline Laudamotion.
Analysts at UBS expect earnings per share of 970 cents during the year to March 2019, compared with 1,200 cents 
in full-year 2018.
While higher fuel prices added to first-half costs, 90 per cent of Ryanair's fuel needs for the next 12 months." are 
hedged at $68 per barrel-well below the $85 spot price. Still, we are wary of recent volatility to turn bullish just yet, 
especially when the shares look expensive compared with their historical two-year trading average and the wider 
sector. Julia Faurschou
Travel & Leisure Ryanair (RYA) HOLD
Load-Date: October 27, 2018
End of Document

Length: 281 words
Body
If the oil price rises, or if average fares fall further, morecapacity cuts look likely for thebudgetcarrier It was a 
turbulent firsthalf for Ryanair following ongoing pilot disputes and air traffic controller strikes in continental Europe. 
In early October, management warned pre-tax profits would land between (EURO)1.1bn (£97m) and (EURO)1.2bn-
a12 per cent downgrade on expectations .
investor.s were pleasantly surprised, then, that this figure actually came to (EURO)1.3bn, with the shares up about 
5 per cent on results day. Passenger numbers increased by 6 per cent to 76.6m, with load factor maintained at 96

Ryanair seeks to deflect criticism of racist incident
Ryanair seeks to deflect criticism of racist incident
Associated Press Financial Wire
October 26, 2018 Friday 1:15 PM GMT
Copyright 2018 Associated Press All Rights Reserved
Section: BUSINESS NEWS
Length: 496 words
Byline: By DANICA KIRKA, Associated Press
Dateline: LONDON 
Body
LONDON (AP) - Ryanair sought to deflect criticism Friday about its handling of a racially charged dispute on one of 
its flights by releasing letters showing that it swiftly apologized to the victim and referred the matter to police.
Europe's biggest discount carrier said in letters to victim that it "will not tolerate unruly behavior" and that the matter 
had been reported to police at London's Stansted Airport. The incident took place Friday at Barcelona Airport before 
the plane departed for Stansted, and British police are expected to hand over the results of their inquiry to Spanish 
authorities.
The move came as the man who directed racial slurs at a fellow passenger denied being a racist and apologized to 
the woman he berated. David Mesher told Britain's ITV News that the dispute with 77-year-old Delsie Gayle began 
as he tried to get to his seat.
"I probably lost my temper a bit and ordered her to get up," he said, adding that he "absolutely" regrets his behavior. 
"I'm not a racist person by any means and it's just a fit of temper at the time, I think."
The interview is the first time Mesher has spoken publicly about the incident, in which he told Gayle, among other 
things, not to speak to him "in a foreign language, you stupid ugly cow." He told ITV he had spoken to police in 
Birmingham, where he lives.
The ramifications of the incident continued to simmer as some passengers have called for a boycott of Ryanair 
because the victim was moved to another seat and the airline didn't remove Mesher from the plane.
Ryanair said it wanted to set the record straight on its response to the incident, reporting that crew members were 
aware of an argument but only learned of the racist nature of the comments after being shown the video upon 
landing at Stansted.
"As the cabin crew believed they were dealing with an argument between two passengers, they followed company 
procedure, to defuse the argument, and separate the passengers by offering to move one to alternative seating," 
Ryanair said in a statement.
Ryanair seeks to deflect criticism of racist incident
The female passenger was moved at her request to a seat next to her daughter, Ryanair said. Both passengers 
then said they were "okay."
"As far as the cabin crew were concerned, that was the end of the matter, and since there was no threat to aircraft 
safety, the issue of offloading one passenger did not arise," the airline said.
Loizos Heracleous, an expert on airlines at the Warwick Business School, said the statement showed that Ryanair 
realized it had to condemn this sort of behavior in any situation, including their own flights.
"Service excellence is not Ryanair's forte (efficiency is)," Heracleous said in an email. "With that focus, 
unfortunately the company and, in this case the crew, may not be as sensitized to instances of abusive behavior as 
they should be and may not take the right actions immediately when it occurs. Hopefully Ryanair will realize from 
the strength of the public response that they should up their game in this area."
Load-Date: October 27, 2018
End of Document
European ADRs Move Lower in Friday Trading
European ADRs Move Lower in Friday Trading
MT Newswires Live Briefs
October 26, 2018 Friday 10:38 AM EST
Copyright 2018 MT Newswires All Rights Reserved
Length: 226 words
Body
 American depositary receipts of European stocks were trading 1.52% lower at 122.86 on the Bank of New York 
Mellon Europe ADR Index on Friday.
In continental Europe, the gainers were led by Nokia (NOK), and biopharmaceutical firm Grifols (GRFS), which 
climbed 3.7% each. They were followed by oil and gas company Eni (E), and kidney dialysis company Fresenius 
Medical Care (FMS), which rose 1.2% and 0.8%.
The decliners in continental Europe were led by biotech firm ERYTECH Pharma (ERYP), and medical equipment 
company Edap (EDAP), which fell 11% and 7.1% respectively. They were followed by pharmaceutical company 
Oasmia Pharmaceutical (OASM), and biotech company Zealand Pharma (ZEAL), which were off  4.1% and 3.8%.
In the UK and Ireland, the gainers were led by mining company Randgold Resources (GOLD), and construction 
materials supplier CRH (CRH), which were up 3.1% and 0.8% respectively. They were followed by gene therapy 
company Nightstar (NITE),  and airline operator Ryanair (RYAAY), which rose 0.6% and 0.2%.
The decliners in the UK and Ireland were led by Royal Bank of Scotland (RBS), and telecommunications operator 
BT Group (BT), which fell 4.3% and 3.8% respectively. They were followed by communications group WPP (WPP), 
and biopharmaceutical firm NuCana (NCNA), which were off 3.8% and 1.1%.
Price: 5.50, Change: +0.18, Percent Change: +3.38
Load-Date: October 27, 2018
End of Document
Brussels baggage-handler strike cancels scores of flights
Brussels baggage-handler strike cancels scores of flights
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
October 26, 2018 Friday 9:12 PM GMT
Copyright 2018 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 208 words
Byline: Helen Fessenden in Brussels
Dateline: Brussels (dpa) - 
Body
A baggage-handler strike at Brussels Airport has caused at least 150 flights to be cancelled or rerouted and left 
hundreds of travellers stranded at the airport overnight, the Belga news service reported on Friday.
The strike began on Thursday evening to protest working conditions at Aviapartner, a services firm. It will last until 6 
am Sunday (0500 GMT), according to the airport's website.
According to union representatives, the two sides are still "very far apart" on any agreement, and talks are on hold, 
Belga reported.
Among the list of strikers' grievances are low wages, understaffing and a bonus that was promised but not fully 
paid. A trade union statement cited "a total absence of social consultation" within the company, Belga reported.
Aviapartner, which handles Brussels baggage for Ryanair, EasyJet, British Airways and TUI Fly, is contracted in 37 
airports in six European countries, according to its website.
The strike comes at a busy travel time ahead of the All Saints' holiday next week, when many schools across 
Belgium have a term break. About 350,000 people are expected to travel via Brussels Airport during this period, 
according to Belga.
Editorial contactsEditing by: Shane Strowmatt, +49 30 2852 31472, <international@dpa.com;
Load-Date: October 27, 2018
Brussels baggage-handler strike cancels scores of flights
End of Document
German airport operator under EU scrutiny for state aid breach
German airport operator under EU scrutiny for state aid breach
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
October 26, 2018 Friday 1:04 PM GMT
Copyright 2018 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 282 words
Byline: Helen Fessenden in Brussels
Dateline: Brussels (dpa) - 
Body
The European Commission has started an investigation into whether the company operating a German regional 
airport violated EU rules on state aid in its treatment of Ryanair.
At issue is Germany's Frankfurt-Hahn airport, located in the state of Rhineland-Palatinate. From 2009 to 2017, the 
state controlled the firm managing the airport, Flughafengesellschaft Frankfurt-Hahn GmbH (FFHG). The HNA 
Group purchased 82.5 per cent of FFHG in 2017.
Brussels opened an investigation after receiving a complaint that the airport was giving favourable treatment to the 
budget carrier Ryanair, the commission said Friday in a statement.
The probe will look at agreements between Ryanair and the state prior to 2009, and between Ryanair and FFHG 
after 2009, to see if the carrier received preferential treatment.
The post-2009 agreements under review include deals covering airport service agreements, training aid to Ryanair 
and other projects.
The commission will also investigate whether certain land sale agreements between the state and FFHG ran afoul 
of EU competition rules.
Under these rules, states may provide assistance to regional airports if it helps local development, connectivity and 
traffic decongestion. This aid may include subsidies to budget airlines.
Publically owned airports, however, cannot extend incentives that exceed what a profit-driven airport operator would 
offer under the same conditions.
German airport operator under EU scrutiny for state aid breach
The commission has already concluded numerous other probes into airports and state aid, including cases in 
France, Germany, Austria, and Italy - all of which found instances of EU state aid violations.
Editorial contactsEditing by: Monica Raymunt, +49 30 2852 31472; <international@dpa.com;
Load-Date: October 27, 2018
End of Document
Brussels baggage-handler strike cancels scores of flights
Brussels baggage-handler strike cancels scores of flights
dpa-AFX International ProFeed
October 26, 2018 Friday 9:14 PM GMT

Length: 207 words
Body
       By Helen Fessenden   BRUSSELS (dpa-AFX) - A baggage-handler strike at Brussels Airport has caused at 
least 150 flights to be cancelled or rerouted and left hundreds of travellers stranded at the airport overnight, the 
Belga news service reported on Friday.  The strike began on Thursday evening to protest working conditions at 
Aviapartner, a services firm. It will last until 6 am Sunday (0500 GMT), according to the airport's website.  According 
to union representatives, the two sides are still 'very far apart' on any agreement, and talks are on hold, Belga 
reported.  Among the list of strikers' grievances are low wages, understaffing and a bonus that was promised but 
not fully paid. A trade union statement cited 'a total absence of social consultation' within the company, Belga 
reported.  Aviapartner, which handles Brussels baggage for Ryanair, EasyJet, British Airways and TUI Fly, is 
contracted in 37 airports in six European countries, according to its website.  The strike comes at a busy travel time 
ahead of the All Saints' holiday next week, when many schools across Belgium have a term break. About 350,000 
people are expected to travel via Brussels Airport during this period, according to Belga.   Copyright dpa

German airport operator under EU scrutiny for state aid breach
dpa-AFX International ProFeed
October 26, 2018 Friday 1:05 PM GMT
Copyright 2018 dpa-AFX Wirtschaftsnachrichten GmbH All Rights Reserved
Length: 278 words
Body
       BRUSSELS (dpa-AFX) - The European Commission has started an investigation into whether the company 
operating a German regional airport violated EU rules on state aid in its treatment of Ryanair.  At issue is 
Germany's Frankfurt-Hahn airport, located in the state of Rhineland-Palatinate. 
From 2009 to 2017, the state controlled the firm managing the airport, Flughafengesellschaft Frankfurt-Hahn GmbH 
(FFHG). The HNA Group purchased 82.5 per cent of FFHG in 2017.  Brussels opened an investigation after 
receiving a complaint that the airport was giving favourable treatment to the budget carrier Ryanair, the commission 
said Friday in a statement.  The probe will look at agreements between Ryanair and the state prior to 2009, and 
between Ryanair and FFHG after 2009, to see if the carrier received preferential treatment.   The post-2009 
agreements under review include deals covering airport service agreements, training aid to Ryanair and other 
projects.  The commission will also investigate whether certain land sale agreements between the state and FFHG 
ran afoul of EU competition rules.  Under these rules, states may provide assistance to regional airports if it helps 
local development, connectivity and traffic decongestion. This aid may include subsidies to budget airlines.  
Publically owned airports, however, cannot extend incentives that exceed what a profit-driven airport operator would 
offer under the same conditions.   The commission has already concluded numerous other probes into airports and 
state aid, including cases in France, Germany, Austria, and Italy - all of which found instances of EU state aid 
violations.   Copyright dpa

hundreds of travellers stranded at the airport overnight, the Belga news service reported on Friday.
The strike began on Thursday evening to protest working conditions at Aviapartner, a services firm. It will last until 6 
am Saturday (0400 GMT), according to a tweet by the airport.
According to union representatives, the two sides are still "very far apart" on any agreement, and talks are on hold, 
Belga reported.
Among the list of strikers' grievances are low wages, understaffing and a bonus that was promised but not fully 
paid. A trade union statement cited "a total absence of social consultation" within the company, Belga reported.
Aviapartner, which handles Brussels baggage for Ryanair, EasyJet, British Airways and TUI Fly, is contracted in 37 
airports in six European countries, according to its website.
The strike comes at a busy travel time ahead of the All Saints' holiday next week, when many schools across 
Belgium have a term break. About 350,000 people are expected to travel via Brussels Airport during this period, 
according to Belga.
Editorial contactsEditing by: Shane Strowmatt, +49 30 2852 31472, <international@dpa.com;
Load-Date: October 27, 2018

       By Helen Fessenden   BRUSSELS (dpa-AFX) - A baggage-handler strike at Brussels Airport has caused at

Belga news service reported on Friday.  The strike began on Thursday evening to protest working conditions at 
Aviapartner, a services firm. It will last until 6 am Saturday (0400 GMT), according to a tweet by the airport.  
According to union representatives, the two sides are still 'very far apart' on any agreement, and talks are on hold, 
Belga reported.  Among the list of strikers' grievances are low wages, understaffing and a bonus that was promised 
but not fully paid. A trade union statement cited 'a total absence of social consultation' within the company, Belga 
reported.  Aviapartner, which handles Brussels baggage for Ryanair, EasyJet, British Airways and TUI Fly, is 
contracted in 37 airports in six European countries, according to its website.  The strike comes at a busy travel time 
ahead of the All Saints' holiday next week, when many schools across Belgium have a term break. About 350,000 
people are expected to travel via Brussels Airport during this period, according to Belga.   Copyright dpa

Seven Eight Capital LP Buys Shares of 11,805 Ryanair Holdings plc (RYAAY)
Seven Eight Capital LP Buys Shares of 11,805 Ryanair Holdings plc (RYAAY)
American Banking and Market News
October 26, 2018 Friday
Copyright 2018 American Banking and Market News All Rights Reserved
Length: 720 words
Body
Ryanair logo Seven Eight Capital LP acquired a new stake in shares of  Ryanair Holdings plc (NASDAQ:RYAAY) 
during the third quarter, according to the company in its most recent 13F filing with the Securities and Exchange 
Commission (SEC). The institutional investor  acquired 11,805 shares of the transportation company's stock, valued 
at approximately $1,134,000.  
A number of other institutional investors also recently modified their holdings of RYAAY. Baillie Gifford & Co. lifted 
its holdings in  Ryanair by 2.3% in the second quarter. Baillie Gifford & Co. now owns 5,936,962 shares of the 
transportation company's stock valued at $678,179,000 after acquiring an additional 133,294 shares during the 
period.  WCM Investment Management CA lifted its stake in shares of  Ryanair by 3.9% in the 2nd quarter. WCM 
Investment Management CA now owns 3,866,003 shares of the transportation company's stock worth 
$441,614,000 after purchasing an additional 146,752 shares during the period.  Massachusetts Financial Services 
Co. MA raised its position in  Ryanair by 14.5% in the second quarter. Massachusetts Financial Services Co. MA 
now owns 2,539,197 shares of the transportation company's stock worth $290,053,000 after acquiring an additional 
321,859 shares during the period.  Bank of America Corp DE raised its position in  Ryanair by 2.7% in the second 
quarter. Bank of America Corp DE now owns 561,841 shares of the transportation company's stock worth 
$64,178,000 after acquiring an additional 15,020 shares during the period.  Finally, Bank of Montreal Can raised its 
position in  Ryanair by 9.1% in the second quarter. Bank of Montreal Can now owns 421,083 shares of the 
transportation company's stock worth $48,101,000 after acquiring an additional 35,003 shares during the period. 
Institutional investors own  43.93% of the company's stock.  
RYAAY has been the topic of several recent research reports. ValuEngine  downgraded Ryanair from a "hold" 
rating to a "sell" rating in a research note on Tuesday, July 24th. BidaskClub downgraded Ryanair from a "hold" 
rating to a "sell" rating in a research note on Tuesday, August 7th. Raymond James downgraded Ryanair from an 
"outperform" rating to a "market perform" rating in a research note on Thursday, August 9th. Royal Bank of Canada  
restated a "buy" rating on shares of Ryanair in a research note on Thursday, August 16th. Finally, UBS Group  
restated a "buy" rating on shares of Ryanair in a research note on Wednesday, August 15th. Two investment 
analysts have rated the stock with a sell rating, seven have given a hold rating and three have assigned  a buy 
rating to the company. The stock  has a consensus rating of "Hold" and an average target price of $138.00. 
Shares of RYAAY stock  opened at $81.15 on Friday. The firm has a market cap of $19.72 billion, a PE ratio of 
11.51 and a beta of 0.55. Ryanair Holdings plc has a one year low of $77.96 and a one year high of $127.61. The 
company has a debt-to-equity ratio of 0.72, a quick ratio of 1.12 and a current ratio of 1.12.  
Seven Eight Capital LP Buys Shares of 11,805 Ryanair Holdings plc (RYAAY)
Ryanair (NASDAQ:RYAAY) last posted its quarterly earnings results on Monday, July 23rd. The transportation 
company reported $1.62 EPS for the quarter, beating the Zacks' consensus estimate of $1.55 by $0.07. The 
business had revenue of $2.48 billion for the quarter, compared to analysts' expectations of $2.41 billion. Ryanair 
had a return on equity of 29.19% and a net margin of 18.47%.  On average, equities analysts forecast that  Ryanair 
Holdings plc will post 5.65 EPS for the current fiscal year.  
About Ryanair
Ryanair Holdings plc, together with its subsidiaries, provides scheduled-passenger airline services in Ireland, the 
United Kingdom, and Other European countries. The company is also involved in the provision of various ancillary 
services, such as non-flight scheduled services and Internet-related services; in-flight sale of beverages, food, and 
merchandise; and marketing accommodation services, holidays, car hire, and travel insurance through its Website.

Strike at Brussels airport leaves hundreds stranded
Strike at Brussels airport leaves hundreds stranded
Associated Press Financial Wire
October 26, 2018 Friday 12:21 PM GMT
Copyright 2018 Associated Press All Rights Reserved
Section: BUSINESS NEWS
Length: 94 words
Dateline: BRUSSELS 
Body
BRUSSELS (AP) - Hundreds of passengers have been left stranded at Brussels international airport after luggage 
handlers went on strike over workload and pay demands.
Overnight, several hundred passengers had to spend the night in the airport after their planes were left stranded. By 
noon on Friday, well over 100 flights had been canceled. Some passengers had to line up for hours, hoping to still 
get a flight at the start of the autumn holiday season.
The Aviapartner luggage handling company serves major companies like Ryanair, TUI, EasyJet and British 
Airways.
